Pixlee | spouse = [[Andy Smith (entrepreneur)|Andy Smith]] | website = http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/ }} '''Jennifer Aaker''' (born 1967, California) is an American social psychologist, author and General Atlantic Professor of Marketing at [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]. Best known for her research on time, money and happiness,{{cite web|last=Cook|first=Nancy|title=The Corporate Pursuit of Happiness|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1722637/corporate-pursuit-happiness|work=March, 2011|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=19 June 2013}} Aaker also focuses on the transmission of ideas through social networks, the power of story in decision making, and how to build global brands across cultures.{{cite web|title=The Brainiacs: Most Influential Women In Technology|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/women-in-tech/2011/brainiacs/jennifer-aaker|work=2011|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=4 June 2013}}{{cite web|title=Faculty Profile: Jennifer Aaker|url=http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/|publisher=Stanford Graduate School of Business|accessdate=6 June 2013}} She is the recipient of the Distinguished Scientific Achievement Award from the [[Society for Consumer Psychology]] and the Stanford Distinguished Teaching Award.{{cite web|title=Jennifer Aaker: Psychology Today |url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/experts/jennifer-aaker |work=2014 |publisher=Psychology Today |accessdate=27 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306113958/http://www.psychologytoday.com/experts/jennifer-aaker |archivedate= 6 March 2014 |df= }} == Early life and education == Aaker was born in [[Palo Alto, California]], to Kay Aaker,{{cite web|last=Wake|first=Jennifer|title=The Gift of Time: Skilled Volunteers Found in Local Retirees|url=http://www.volunteereastbay.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/The_Gift_of_Time.pdf|work=April 15, 2009|publisher=La Morinda Weekly|accessdate=7 June 2013}} and [[David Aaker]], a professor and brand consultant.{{cite web|title=David A. Aaker, Author Profile|url=http://authors.simonandschuster.com/David-A-Aaker/1451364|publisher=Simon and Schuster|accessdate=7 June 2013}} Aaker attended the [[University of California, Berkeley]], where she studied under social psychologist [[Philip E. Tetlock]] and [[Nobel Prize]] winner [[Daniel Kahneman]], receiving a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Psychology]] in 1989. In 1990, Aaker began postgraduate work at Stanford Graduate School of Business, earning a Ph.D. in marketing with a minor in psychology in 1995. Her dissertation on brand personality led to the publication of three academic papers in ''Journal of Marketing Research'' and ''Journal of Consumer Research'' and won several awards.{{cite web|title=Honors and Recognition |url=http://faculty.gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/documents/Aaker_Vita.pdf |work=2013 |publisher=Stanford University |accessdate=15 June 2013 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Career == Aaker began her academic career in 1995 as an assistant professor at the [[UCLA Anderson School of Management]]. In 1999, she returned to the Stanford Graduate School of Business as an assistant professor, was promoted to associate professor in 2001, and earned a full professorship in 2004. In 2005, Aaker was named General Atlantic Professor of Marketing.{{cite web|title=Aaker CV at Stanford Graduate School of Business |url=http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/documents/Aaker_Vita.pdf |work=January, 2013 |publisher=Stanford University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130722150424/http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/documents/Aaker_Vita.pdf |archivedate=2013-07-22 |df= }} Her work has been published in scholarly journals in psychology and marketing and has been highlighted in ''[[The Economist]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek|BusinessWeek]]'', ''[[Forbes]],'' [[NPR]], ''[[CBS MoneyWatch]]'', ''[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]'' and ''[[Science (journal)|Science]].'' She serves as an advisory board member for several private companies. As a social psychologist and marketer, Aaker began her research career by proposing a "Dimensions of Brand Personality" framework to describe and measure the "personality" of a brand, defined as the set of human characteristics associated with it. The five core dimensions are Sincerity, Excitement, Competence, Sophistication, and Ruggedness. In a global analysis of brands, Aaker and her colleagues revealed two novel brand personality dimensions. In Japan, individuals viewed brands as Peaceful, and in Spain, individuals viewed brands as Passionate. Aaker’s model showed that brand personality dimensions influence consumer preference and choice and provided a framework that illuminated how to build strong global brands that meet multi-cultural needs.{{cite journal|last=Aaker|first=Jennifer|title=Dimensions of Brand Personality|date=August 1997|url=http://www.haas.berkeley.edu/groups/finance/Papers/Dimensions%20of%20BP%20JMR%201997.pdf|accessdate=16 June 2013}} In 2002, Aaker shifted her research focus to understanding time, money and happiness. In this work, she suggested that time is a resource that, like money, is not only important but more subjective than we think. In 2010, she published two papers with [[Sepandar Kamvar|Sep Kamvar]] and Cassie Mogilner on the dynamic meaning of happiness. Prior research had suggested that the meaning of happiness is either similar across individuals, or highly subjective and idiosyncratic. Aaker and her colleagues show that the answer lies between the two and that there is in fact a predictable shift in the meaning of happiness and how it is experienced over one's life and even within the day or week. The research also showed that the meaning of happiness that one holds impacts the choices people make. Aaker has also examined questions such as why people give to others, how small acts create significant change, and how those effects can be fueled by social media. In 2010, Aaker and her husband, startup advisor Andy Smith, authored the book ''The Dragonfly Effect: Quick, Effective and Powerful Ways to Use Social Media to Drive Social Change.''{{cite web|title=The Dragonfly Effect|url=http://www.dragonflyeffect.com/|work=2013|publisher=Official Website|accessdate=16 June 2013}} With a title inspired by the dragonfly’s unique ability to propel itself in any direction when its four wings worked in concert, the book examined the manner in which synchronized ideas can be used to create rapid transformations through social media. A literary award winner,[5] ''The Dragonfly Effect'' has been translated into over 10 languages. In 2013, Aaker, Smith and McCarthy published ''The Power of Stories'', a companion to ''The Dragonfly Effect'', which further explored social media through psychological insight and provided a hands-on tool to help companies put the model to work. In a real world demonstration of the Dragonfly Effect, Aaker and her students founded 100K Cheeks,.{{cite web|last=David|first=Avril|title=Names You Need to Know|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/avrildavid/2011/05/17/names-you-need-to-know-the-dragonfly-effect/|work=May 17, 2011|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=16 June 2013}}{{Cite book|title=The Power of Stores|ISBN=1484184386}} an organization dedicated to registering 100,000 South Asian donors in the National Bone Marrow Registry.{{cite web|title=Past Challenges (Get Involved) |url=http://studentaffairs.stanford.edu/haas/100kcheeks |publisher=Haas Center for Public Service |accessdate=13 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221230214/http://studentaffairs.stanford.edu/haas/100kcheeks |archivedate=21 December 2013 |df= }} In addition to utilizing social networks, Aaker ran the first ever cheek swab in India; as a result of these efforts, 100K Cheeks exceeded their goal by registering more than 115,000 potential donors.{{cite web|title=Jennifer Aaker: Pursuit of Happiness|url=http://www.inktalks.com/discover/53/pursuit-of-happiness|work=November 27, 2011|publisher=Ink Talks|accessdate=19 June 2013}}{{cite book|last=Beth Kanter Katie Delahaye Paine|first=Katie Delahaye Paine|title=Measuring the Networked Nonprofit: Using Data to Change the World|year=2012|publisher=Wiley|location=New York|isbn=978-1-118-13760-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=vL_lhYF0Uf4C&pg=PT36&lpg=PT36&dq=jennifer+aaker+100k+cheeks}}{{cite web|title=The Dragonfly Effect|url=http://www.ssireview.org/articles/entry/the_dragonfly_effect|work=October 2011|publisher=Stanford Social Innovation Review|accessdate=16 June 2013}} "Social media is not inherently meaningful," Aaker said in an interview on the subject. "Yet the power of social technology, when fully engaged, can be nothing short of revolutionary."{{cite web|last=Staff Writer|title=100k Cheeks and Blood Center to Host Marrow Drive|url=http://www.stanforddaily.com/2011/02/01/100k-cheeks-and-blood-center-to-host-bone-marrow-drive/|work=February 1, 2011|publisher=Stanford Daily|accessdate=16 June 2013}} == Books == * {{cite book |first1= Jennifer |last1= Aaker |title= The Dragonfly Effect: Quick, Effective, and Powerful Ways To Use Social Media to Drive Social Change |first2= Andy |last2= Smith |date= September 2010 |publisher= Jossey-Bass |isbn= 978-0-470-61415-0 }}{{cite book |title= The Dragonfly Effect: Quick, Effective, and Powerful Ways To Use Social Media to Drive Social Change |first1= Jennifer Lynn |last1= Aaker |first2= Andy |last2= Smith |others= Carlye Adler |publisher= Jossey-Bass |location= San Francisco |date= 2010 |isbn= 9780470614150 |oclc= 460061966 }} * {{cite book |first3= Jennifer |last3= Aaker |title= Dragonfly Effect Workbook: The Power of Stories |first1= Andrew |last1= Smith |first2= Barbara |last2= McCarthy |date= April 2013 |publisher= [[CreateSpace]] |isbn= 978-1-4841-8438-7 |url= https://www.createspace.com/4255497 }} * {{cite book |contributor-first1= Jennifer |contributor-last1= Aaker |contribution= Text |title= Keep Calm, Play Hard: One Player's Journey in New York City |first1= Cooper |last1= Smith |date= November 2013 |isbn= 978-1494278342 |publisher= CreateSpace |url= https://www.createspace.com/4542264 }} * {{cite book |contributor-first1= Jennifer |contributor-last1= Aaker |contribution= Text |title= Tea Sloane's Adventure: A Sparkly Tale of Whimsy and Meaning Found in NYC |first1= Tea Sloane |last1= Smith |date= December 2013 |publisher= CreateSpace |isbn= 9781494471064 |url= https://www.createspace.com/4570510 }} * {{cite book |contributor-first1= Jennifer |contributor-last1= Aaker |contribution= Text |title= Devon Made It: One Boy's Journey in NYC |first1= Devon |last1= Smith |date= December 2013 |url= https://www.createspace.com/4560010 |isbn= 9781494400811 |publisher= CreateSpace }} == Selected publications == * {{cite journal |title= Some Key Differences between a Happy Life and a Meaningful Life |first= Roy F. |last1= Baumeister |first2= Kathleen D. |last2= Vohs |first3= Jennifer |last3= Aaker |first4= Emily N. |last4= Garbinsky |journal= Journal of Positive Psychology |date= 2013 |volume= 8 |issue= 6 |pages= 505–516 |url= https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/faculty-research/publications/some-key-differences-between-happy-life-meaningful-life |doi= 10.1080/17439760.2013.830764 }} *''How Happiness Impacts Choice'' (2012), Mogilner, Aaker and Kamvar, JCR *''Awe Expands People's Perception of Time and Enhances Well-Being'' (2012), Rudd, Vohs, and Aaker, Psychological Science. *''If Money Doesn't Make You Happy, Consider Time'' (2011), Aaker, Rudd, and Mogilner, JCP *''The Shifting Meaning of Happiness'' (2010) Mogilner, Kamvar and Aaker, SPPS *''Non-Profits Are Seen as Warm and For-Profits as Competent'' (2010), Aaker, Vohs and Mogilner, JCR *''The Time versus Money Effect'' (2009), Mogilner and Aaker, JCR *''The Happiness of Giving: The Time-Ask Effect'' (2008), Liu and Aaker, JCR *''When Good Brands Do Bad'' (2004), Aaker, Fournier, and Brasel, JCR *''Can Mixed Emotions Peacefully Co-Exist?'' (2002), Williams and Aaker, JCR *''Consumption Symbols as Carriers of Culture'' (2001), Aaker, Benet-Martínez, and Garolera, JPSP *''Dimensions of Brand Personality'' (1997), Aaker, JMR == Honors and awards == *Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award, Society for Consumer Psychology, 2014{{cite web|title=SCP Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award|url=http://www.apa.org/about/awards/div-23-scpscicon.aspx?tab=4|publisher=[[American Psychological Association]]|accessdate=May 9, 2015}} *Robert K. Jaedicke Silver Apple Award, Stanford, 2011{{cite web|title=Robert K. Jaedicke Silver Apple Award recipients|url=http://www.gsb.stanford.edu/alumni/featured-events/award-events/silver-apple|publisher=[[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]|accessdate=May 9, 2015}} *Early Career Award for Outstanding Research, Society for Consumer Psychology, 2003{{cite web|title=Honorees |url=http://www.myscp.org/about/honorees.aspx#.VU5zFvlViko |publisher=Society for Consumer Psychology |accessdate=May 9, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130324234737/http://www.myscp.org/about/honorees.aspx |archivedate=March 24, 2013 |df= }} *Distinguished Teaching Award, Stanford, 2000 *Citibank Best Teacher Award, UCLA, 1999 *George Robbins Best Teacher Award, UCLA, 1998 == See also== * [[Innovation]] * [[Creativity]] * [[Narrative|Story]] * [[Design thinking]] * [[Customer engagement]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/ Jennifer Aaker at Stanford Graduate School of Business] *[http://www.stanford.edu/class/mktg353/ Building Innovative Brands] *[http://stanford.edu/class/gsbgen542/ The Power of Story] *[http://www.stanford.edu/class/mktg355/ Designing (for) Happiness] *[http://www.dragonflyeffect.com/ The Dragonfly Effect] {{DEFAULTSORT:Aaker, Jennifer}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American social psychologists]] [[Category:American marketing people]] [[Category:Stanford Graduate School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University Graduate School of Business faculty]] [[Category:Marketing theorists]] [[Category:Marketing women]] [[Category:People from Lafayette, California]] [[Category:Writers from Palo Alto, California]]

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=January 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Lee Aaker | image = Paul Birch Lee Aaker Rin Tin Tin 1956.jpg | caption = Lee Aaker and Rin Tin Tin (1956) | birth_name = Lee William Aaker | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|9|25}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = Actor, producer, carpenter, ski instructor | years_active = 1951–1963 <small>(actor)</small> | spouse = Sharon Ann Hamilton (1969-71) (divorced) | residence = [[Mammoth Lakes, California]] | website = }} [[File:Rin Tin Tin main cast 1956.jpg|thumb|right|Lee Aaker with [[Rin Tin Tin]], [[James Brown (actor)|James Brown]], and [[Rand Brooks]] ]] '''Lee William Aaker''' (born September 25, 1943)<ref name="Goldrup">Goldrup, Tom & Goldrup, Jim (2002) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=3PsGWOPQtKQC&pg=PA5&dq=%22lee+aaker%22&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22lee%20aaker%22&f=false Growing Up on the Set: Interviews with 39 Former Child Actors of Classic Film and Television]'', McFarland & Co Inc, {{ISBN|978-0-7864-1254-9}}, p. 5-12</ref> is an American former [[child actor]] known for his appearance as Rusty "B-Company" in the television program ''[[The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin]]''.
== Early years == Aaker's mother, Mrs. Myles Wilbour,<ref name="t">{{cite news|title='Corporal Rusty' Battles Indians On Television and Books With Tutor|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7657387/the_times/|work=The Times|agency=International News Service|date=October 28, 1956|location=Indiana, Hammond|page=85|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = November 26, 2016}} {{Open access}}</ref> was the owner of a dancing school in Los Angeles.<ref name="rtt">{{cite book|last1=Orlean|first1=Susan|title=Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend|date=2011|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439190159|page=191|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HoV2pziYT34C&pg=PA291&dq=%22Lee+Aaker%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjHjeW7v8_QAhUi_IMKHW_qCK0Q6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=%22Lee%20Aaker%22&f=false|accessdate=30 November 2016|language=en}}</ref> (Another source says that she "ran a children's theatre academy" and that at age 4 she had Aaker "singing and dancing at local clubs.")<ref name="xcs">{{cite book|last1=Garver|first1=Kathy|last2=Ascher|first2=Fred|title=X Child Stars: Where Are They Now?|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9781630761141|pages=32–33|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V3GoCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA32&dq=%22Lee+Aaker%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjHjeW7v8_QAhUi_IMKHW_qCK0Q6AEIUjAJ#v=onepage&q=%22Lee%20Aaker%22&f=false|accessdate=30 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
== Film == On television as a young child, he started appearing uncredited at the age of 8 in films such as ''[[The Greatest Show on Earth (film)|The Greatest Show on Earth]]'' (1952) and ''[[High Noon]]'' (1952).<ref name="Goldrup" /> He quickly moved to featured status by the end of that year.
He showed talent as the kidnapped Indian "Red Chief" in a segment of the film ''[[O. Henry's Full House]]'' (1952) and another kidnap victim as the son of scientist [[Gene Barry]] in ''[[The Atomic City]]'' (1952).
In 1953, he co-starred in the [[John Wayne]] [[Western (genre)|western]] classic ''[[Hondo (film)|Hondo]]'' (1953) as the [[curious]] [[blond]] son of homesteader [[Geraldine Page]].<ref name="Goldrup" />
He also appeared in other film styles such as the ''[[film noir]]'' thriller ''[[Jeopardy (film)|Jeopardy]]'' (1953) with [[Barbara Stanwyck]], the horse opera drama ''Arena'' (1953) with [[Gig Young]], and the comedies ''[[Mister Scoutmaster]]'' (1953) with [[Clifton Webb]] and ''[[Ricochet Romance]]'' (1954) with [[Marjorie Main]].
== Television == In 1953-54, Aaker was among the many child actors who auditioned for the role of "Jeff Miller" on the original 1954 ''[[Lassie (1954 TV series)|Lassie]]'' series, which later aired as ''Jeff's Collie''. That role went to [[Tommy Rettig]]. Two weeks later, Aaker won the role of "Rusty" on ''The Adventures of Rin-Tin-Tin'', co-starring [[James Brown (Rin Tin Tin)|James Brown]] (1920–1992) as [[Lieutenant]] Ripley "Rip" Masters.<ref name="Goldrup" /> Aaker and Rettig were friends, and both shows were popular with audiences. The two actors and the two star dogs appeared together in a photograph used on the cover of the July 2, 1955 issue of ''[[TV Guide]]''.{{r|rtt|page1=236}}
== Later years == Aaker told a newspaper reporter that when he reached the age of 21, he was paid a $10,000 lump sum by the studio that produced ''Rin Tin Tin'' "and he spent the rest of the '60s traveling around the world 'as sort of a flower child.'"<ref name="si">{{cite news|title=Rin Tin Tin's friend is now a carpenter|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/85252305/?terms=%22Lee%2BAaker%22|work=Southern Illinoisan|date=November 15, 1976|location=Illinois, Carbondale|page=18|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = November 30, 2016}} {{Open access}}</ref> Unable to find work as an adult actor, Aaker got involved as a producer and later worked as a carpenter.<ref name="Goldrup" />
==Personal life== In the late 1960s, Aaker was married to Sharon Ann Hamilton for two years.<ref name=xcs/> He has resided in [[Mammoth Lakes, California|Mammoth Lakes]], [[California]], for many years and is a special-needs ski instructor.<ref name="Goldrup" />
==Recognition== In 2005, Aaker won the [[Golden Boot Awards|Golden Boot Award]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Golden Boot Awards|url=http://www.b-westerns.com/goldboot.htm|website=The Old Corral|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> as ''Kids of the West''.
==Filmography==

Dorset aka Red Chief (The Ransom of Red Chief) | |- | 1952 | ''Desperate Search'' | Don Heldon | |- | 1952 | ''[[Hans Christian Andersen (film)|Hans Christian Andersen]]'' | Little Boy | Uncredited |- | 1953 | ''[[Jeopardy (film)|Jeopardy]]'' | Bobby Stilwin | |- | 1953 | ''Take Me to Town'' | Corney Hall | |- | 1953 | ''Arena'' | Teddy Hutchins | |- | 1953 | ''[[Mister Scoutmaster]]'' | Arthur | |- | 1953 | ''[[A Lion Is in the Streets]]'' | Johnny Briscoe | |- | 1953 | ''[[Hondo (film)|Hondo]]'' | Johnny Lowe | |- | 1954 | ''[[Ride Clear of Diablo]]'' | Boy | Uncredited |- | 1954 | ''The Raid'' | Larry's Friend | Uncredited |- | 1954 | ''Her Twelve Men'' | Michael Elliot | Uncredited |- | 1954 | ''[[Ricochet Romance]]'' | Timmy Williams | |- | 1954 | ''Destry'' | Eli Skinner | |- | 1954 | ''[[Black Tuesday (film)|Black Tuesday]]'' | Little Boy | |- | 1955 | ''Spin and Marty: The Movie'' | Russell the Muscle | |- | 1956 | ''Bigger Than Life'' | Joe | Uncredited |- | 1957 | ''The Challenge of Rin Tin Tin'' | Rusty | |- | 1963 | ''[[Bye Bye Birdie (film)|Bye Bye Birdie]]'' | Student leader | Uncredited |}

Notes |- | 1952 | ''Your Jeweler's Showcase'' | | Episode: "Teacher of the Year" |- | 1953 | ''[[Fireside Theatre]]'' | Sandy | Episode: "The Boy Down the Road" |- | 1953–1954 | ''[[The Ford Television Theatre]]'' |Tony Evans / Joey | 3 episodes |- | 1954 | ''[[Schlitz Playhouse of Stars]]'' | | Episode: "Pearl-Handled Guns" |- | 1954 | ''[[General Electric Theater]]'' | Tim Kelly | Episode: "Wild Luke's Boy" |- | 1955 | ''[[The Adventures of Spin and Marty]]'' on ''[[Walt Disney Presents]]'' | Russell | |- | 1955 | ''[[The Lone Ranger]]'' | Tommy Righter | Episode: "The School Story" |- | 1953–1955 | ''Letter to Loretta'' |Jimmy Preston / Myron | 2 episodes |- | 1955 | ''[[Screen Directors Playhouse]]'' | Cowhide | Episode: "The Brush Roper" |- | December 20, 1956; December 19, 1957 | ''[[The Ford Show|The Ford Show, Starring Tennessee Ernie Ford]]'' | (two [[Christmas]] episodes, with Rin Tin Tin) | |- | 1957 | ''[[Tales of the 77th Bengal Lancers]]'' | Govinda | Episode: "The Glass Necklace" |- | 1959 | ''[[The Millionaire (TV series)|The Millionaire]]'' | Tommy Spencer | Episode: "Millionaire Henry Banning" |- | 1954–1959 | ''[[The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin]]'' | Rusty | 164 episodes |- | 1959 | ''[[Rescue 8]]'' | Billy | Episode: "Runaway" |- | 1959–1961 | ''[[The Donna Reed Show]]'' | Walter the Wizard / Kenny | 2 episodes |- | 1959–1962 | ''[[Walt Disney anthology television series|Disneyland]]'' | Willy / Chuck Taylor | 4 episodes |- | 1960 | ''[[Make Room For Daddy]]'' | Charles Crane | Episode: "Rusty Meets Little Lord Fauntleroy" |- | 1963 | ''[[The Lucy Show]]'' | Cadet Blake | Episode: "Lucy and the Military Academy" |}

revision.comment: Fix broken link: K_4 Crystal formerly linked to a non-existent section in "Toshikazu Sunada". Linking it to "Laves graph".
revision.text:
'''Metachirality''' is a stronger form of [[chirality]]. It applies to objects or systems that are [[chiral]] (not identical to their [[mirror image]]) and where, in addition, their mirror image has a [[symmetry group]] that differs from the symmetry group of the original object or system.<ref>Conway, John H.; Burgiel, Heidi; Goodman-Strauss, Chaim (2008). ''The Symmetries of Things'', p. 353. A K Peters Ltd., London. {{ISBN|978 1 56881 220 5}}.</ref>
Many familiar chiral objects, like the capital letter 'Z' embedded in the plane, are not metachiral. The symmetry group of the capital letter 'Z' embedded in the plane consists of the [[identity transformation]] and a rotation over 180˚ (a half turn). In this case, the mirror image has the same symmetry group. In particular, asymmetric objects (that only have the identity transformation as symmetry, like a human hand) are not metachiral, since the mirror image is also asymmetric. In general, two-dimensional objects and bounded three-dimensional objects are not metachiral.
An example of a metachiral object is an infinite [[helical staircase]]. A [[helix]] in 3D has a ''handedness'' (either left or right, like [[screw thread]]), whereby it differs from its mirror image. An infinite helical staircase, however, does have symmetries: [[screw operation]]s, that is, a combination of a [[translation]] and a [[rotation]]. The symmetry group of the mirror image of an infinite helical staircase also contains screw operations. But they are of the opposite handedness and, hence, the symmetry groups differ. Note, however, that these symmetry groups are [[isomorphic]].
Of the 219 [[space group]]s, 11 are metachiral. A nice example of a metachiral spatial structure is the [[Laves_graph|K<sub>4</sub> crystal]],<ref>[[Toshikazu Sunada|Sunada, Toshikazu]] (Feb. 2008). "Crystals That Nature Might Miss Creating", ''Notices of the AMS'', Volume 55, Number 2, pages 208-215. [http://www.newton.ac.uk/preprints/NI07042.pdf preprint]</ref> also known as Triamond, and featured in the ''Bamboozle'' mathematical artwork.<ref>[http://www.win.tue.nl/bamboozle Bamboozle: A Mathematical Artwork in MetaForum]</ref>
==See also== * [[Chirality]] * [[Orientation (mathematics)]] * [[Stereochemistry]] * [[Right-hand rule]] * [[Handedness]] * [[Asymmetry]]
==References== {{reflist}} <!--- After listing your sources please cite them using inline citations and place them after the information they cite. Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. ---> * * * *
==External links==

revision.text:
[[Image:ALH84001 structures.jpg|thumb|Structures found on meteorite fragment [[Allan Hills 84001]]]] '''Nanobacterium''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|n|æ|n|oʊ|b|æ|k|ˈ|t|ɪər|i|əm}} {{respell|NAN|oh|bak|TEER|ee|əm}}, pl. ''nanobacteria'' {{IPAc-en|ˌ|n|æ|n|oʊ|b|æ|k|ˈ|t|ɪər|i|ə}} {{respell|NAN|oh|bak|TEER|ee|ə}}) is the unit or member name of a proposed class of living [[organism]]s, specifically [[cell wall|cell-walled]] [[microorganisms]] with a size much smaller than the generally accepted lower limit for life (about 200 [[nanometer|nm]] for [[Bacteria#Morphology|bacteria]], like [[Mycoplasma pneumoniae#Cell biology|mycoplasma]]). Originally based on observed nano-scale structures in geological formations ([[Allan Hills 84001|including one meteorite]]), the status of nanobacteria has been controversial, with some researchers suggesting they are a new class of living organism<ref>{{cite journal |author=Kajander E |title=Nanobacteria—propagating calcifying nanoparticles |journal=Lett Appl Microbiol |volume=42 |issue=6 |pages=549–52 |year=2006 |pmid=16706890 |doi=10.1111/j.1472-765X.2006.01945.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ciftcioglu N, McKay D, Mathew G, Kajander E |title=Nanobacteria: fact or fiction? Characteristics, detection, and medical importance of novel self-replicating, calcifying nanoparticles |journal=J Investig Med |volume=54 |issue=7 |pages=385–94 |year=2006 |pmid=17169260 |doi=10.2310/6650.2006.06018}}</ref> capable of incorporating radiolabeled [[uridine]],<ref name="mayo1" /> and others attributing to them a simpler, [[abiotic]] nature.<ref name=Cisar /><ref name="Martel J, Young JD 2008 5549–54">{{cite journal |vauthors=Martel J, Young JD |title=Purported nanobacteria in human blood as calcium carbonate nanoparticles |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=105 |issue=14 |pages=5549–54 |date=April 2008 |pmid=18385376 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0711744105 |pmc=2291092 |bibcode = 2008PNAS..105.5549M }}</ref> One skeptic dubbed them "the [[cold fusion]] of microbiology", in reference to a notorious episode of supposed erroneous science.<ref>Jack Maniloff, quoted in "The Rise and Fall of Nanobacteria", Young and Martel, ''Scientific American'', January 2010</ref> The term "calcifying nanoparticles" (CNPs) has also been used as a conservative name regarding their possible status as a life form.
Research tends to agree that these structures exist, and appear to replicate in some way.<ref>{{cite journal|pmc=2242841|title=Nanobacteria Are Mineralo Fetuin Complexes|year=2008|volume=4|issue=2|pmid=18282102|last1=Raoult|first1=D|last2=Drancourt|first2=M|last3=Azza|first3=S|last4=Nappez|first4=C|last5=Guieu|first5=R|last6=Rolain|first6=JM|last7=Fourquet|first7=P|last8=Campagna|first8=B|last9=La Scola|first9=B|last10=Mege|first10=Jean-Louis|last11=Mansuelle|first11=Pascal|last12=Lechevalier|first12=Eric|last13=Berland|first13=Yvon|last14=Gorvel|first14=Jean-Pierre|last15=Renesto|first15=Patricia|pages=e41|doi=10.1371/journal.ppat.0040041|journal=PLoS Pathogens|display-authors=8}}</ref> However, the idea that they are living entities has now largely been discarded, and the particles are instead thought to be nonliving crystallizations of minerals and organic molecules.<ref>"The Rise and Fall of Nanobacteria", Young and Martel, ''Scientific American'', January 2010</ref>
==1981–2000== In 1981 Torella and Morita described very small cells called [[ultramicrobacteria]]. Defined as being smaller than 300 nm, by 1982 MacDonell and Hood found that some could pass through a 200 nm membrane. Early in 1989, geologist Robert L. Folk found what he later identified as ''nannobacteria'' (written with double "n"), that is, nanoparticles isolated from geological specimens<ref>A convention has been adopted between researchers to name -or spell- the nanoparticles isolated from geological specimens as ''nannobacteria'', and those from biological specimens as ''nanobacteria''.</ref> in [[travertine]] from hot springs of [[Viterbo]], Italy. Initially searching for a bacterial cause for travertine deposition, [[scanning electron microscope]] examination of the mineral where no bacteria were detectable revealed extremely small objects which appeared to be biological.<!-- 1989 find: Dark Life, pg 44 --> His first oral presentation elicited what he called "mostly a stony silence", at the 1992 [[Geological Society of America]]'s annual convention.<ref name="Folk1997">{{cite web|url=http://naturalscience.com/ns/articles/01-03/ns_folk.html|title=Nanobacteria: surely not figments, but what under heaven are they?|last=Folk|first=Robert L.|date=March 4, 1997|publisher=naturalSCIENCE|accessdate=2008-12-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081209035746/http://naturalscience.com/ns/articles/01-03/ns_folk.html|archivedate=December 9, 2008|df=}}</ref> He proposed that nanobacteria are the principal agents of precipitation of all minerals and crystals on Earth formed in liquid water, that they also cause all oxidation of metals, and that they are abundant in many biological specimens.<ref name="Folk1997" />
In 1996, NASA scientist [[David S. McKay|David McKay]] published a study suggesting the existence of nanofossils — fossils of Martian nanobacteria — in [[ALH84001]], a meteorite originating from Mars and found in Antarctica.<ref name="life">{{cite journal |last=McKay |first=David S. |year=1996 |title=Search for Past Life on Mars: Possible Relic Biogenic Activity in Martian Meteorite ALH84001 |journal=Science |volume=273 |issue=5277 |pages=924–930 |doi=10.1126/science.273.5277.924 |url=|pmid=8688069 |bibcode=1996Sci...273..924M|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
''Nanobacterium sanguineum'' was proposed in 1998 as an explanation of certain kinds of pathologic [[calcification]] ([[apatite]] in [[kidney stone]]s) by [[Finland|Finnish]] researcher [[Olavi Kajander]] and [[Turkey (country)|Turkish]] researcher [[Neva Ciftcioglu]], working at the [[University of Kuopio]] in Finland. According to the researchers the particles [[Self-replication|self-replicated]] in [[microbiological culture]], and the researchers further reported having identified [[DNA]] in these structures by staining.<ref name=Kajander>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kajander E, Ciftçioglu N |title=Nanobacteria: An alternative mechanism for pathogenic intra- and extracellular calcification and stone formation |url=http://www.pnas.org/cgi/content/full/95/14/8274 |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci USA |volume=95 |issue=14 |pages=8274–9 |year=1998 |pmid=9653177 |doi=10.1073/pnas.95.14.8274 |pmc=20966|bibcode = 1998PNAS...95.8274K}}</ref>
A paper published in 2000 by a team led by an [[National Institutes of Health|NIH]] scientist [[John Cisar]] further tested these ideas. It stated that what had previously been described as "self-replication" was a form of [[Crystal structure|crystalline]] growth. The only DNA detected in his specimens was identified as coming from the bacteria ''[[Phyllobacterium myrsinacearum]]'', which is a common contaminant in PCR reactions.<ref name=Cisar >{{cite journal |vauthors=Cisar J, Xu D, Thompson J, Swaim W, Hu L, Kopecko D |title=An alternative interpretation of nanobacteria-induced biomineralization |url=http://www.pnas.org/cgi/content/full/97/21/11511 |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci USA |volume=97 |issue=21 |pages=11511–5 |year=2000 |pmid=11027350 |doi=10.1073/pnas.97.21.11511 |pmc=17231 |bibcode=2000PNAS...9711511C}}</ref>
==2001–present== In 2004 a [[Mayo Clinic]] team led by Franklin Cockerill, John Lieske, and Virginia M. Miller, reported to have isolated nanobacteria from diseased human [[artery|arteries]] and [[kidney stone]]s. Their results were published in 2004 and 2006 respectively.<ref name=mayo1 >{{cite journal |vauthors=Miller V, Rodgers G, Charlesworth J, Kirkland B, Severson S, Rasmussen T, Yagubyan M, Rodgers J, Cockerill F, Folk R, Rzewuska-Lech E, Kumar V, Farell-Baril G, Lieske J |title=Evidence of nanobacterial-like structures in calcified human arteries and cardiac valves |url=http://ajpheart.physiology.org/cgi/content/full/287/3/H1115 |journal=Am J Physiol Heart Circ Physiol |volume=287 |issue=3 |pages=H1115–24 |year=2004 |pmid=15142839 |doi=10.1152/ajpheart.00075.2004}}</ref><ref name=mayo2 >{{cite journal |vauthors=Kumar V, Farell G, Yu S, etal |title=Cell biology of pathologic renal calcification: contribution of crystal transcytosis, cell-mediated calcification, and nanoparticles |journal=J. Investig. Med. |volume=54 |issue=7 |pages=412–24 |date=November 2006 |pmid=17169263 |doi=10.2310/6650.2006.06021}}</ref> Similar findings were obtained in 2005 by László Puskás at the DNA Lab, University of Szeged, Hungary. Dr. Puskás identified these particles in cultures obtained from human atherosclerotic aortic walls and blood samples of atherosclerotic patients but the group was unable to detect DNA in these samples.<ref name=puskas >{{cite journal |vauthors=Puskás L, Tiszlavicz L, Rázga Z, Torday L, Krenács T, Papp J |title=Detection of nanobacteria-like particles in human atherosclerotic plaques |journal=Acta Biol Hung |volume=56 |issue=3–4 |pages=233–45 |year=2005 |pmid=16196199 |doi=10.1556/ABiol.56.2005.3-4.7}}</ref>
In 2005, Ciftcioglu and her research team at [[NASA]] used a rotating [[cell culture]] flask, which simulates some aspects of low-gravity conditions, to culture nanobacteria suspected of rapidly forming kidney stones in astronauts. In this environment, they were found to multiply five times faster than in normal Earth gravity. The study concluded that nanobacteria might have a potential role in forming kidney stones and may need to be screened for in crews pre-flight.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ciftçioglu N, Haddad R, Golden D, Morrison D, McKay D |title=A potential cause for kidney stone formation during space flights: enhanced growth of nanobacteria in microgravity |journal=Kidney Int |volume=67 |issue=2 |pages=483–91 |year=2005 |pmid=15673296 |doi=10.1111/j.1523-1755.2005.67105.x}}</ref>
The February 2008 ''Public Library of Science (PLoS) Pathogens'' article focused on the comprehensive characterization of nanobacteria. The authors say that their results rule out the existence of nanobacteria as [[Life|living]] entities and that they are instead a unique [[Plant propagation|self-propagating]] entity, namely self-propagating mineral-[[fetuin]] complexes.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Raoult D, Drancourt M, Azza S, etal |title=Nanobacteria Are Mineralo Fetuin Complexes |journal=PLoS Pathog. |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=e41 |date=February 2008 |pmid=18282102 |pmc=2242841 |doi=10.1371/journal.ppat.0040041 |url=}}</ref>
An April 2008 ''Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS)'' article also reported that blood nanobacteria are not living organisms and stated that "CaCO<sub>3</sub> precipitates prepared ''in vitro'' are remarkably similar to purported nanobacteria in terms of their uniformly sized, membrane-delineated vesicular shapes, with cellular division-like formations and aggregations in the form of colonies."<ref name="Martel J, Young JD 2008 5549–54"/> The growth of such "biomorphic" inorganic precipitates was studied in detail in a 2009 ''Science'' paper, which showed that unusual crystal growth mechanisms can produce [[witherite]] precipitates from barium chloride and silica solutions that closely resemble primitive organisms.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=García-Ruiz JM, Melero-García E, Hyde ST |title=Morphogenesis of self-assembled nanocrystalline materials of barium carbonate and silica |journal=Science |volume=323 |issue=5912 |pages=362–5 |date=January 2009 |pmid=19150841 |doi=10.1126/science.1165349 |url=http://garciaruiz.com/biomorphs/Science_2009_files/Morphogenesis%20of%20Self-Assembled%20Nanocrystalline_JM_science_2009_1.pdf|bibcode = 2009Sci...323..362G }}</ref> The authors commented on the close resemblance of these crystals to putative nanobacteria, stating that their results showed that evidence for life cannot rest on morphology alone.
Further work on the importance of nanobacteria in geology by R. L. Folk and co-workers includes study of calcium carbonate Bahama ooids,<ref>Folk, RL and Lynch. FL (2001) Organic matter, putative nanobacteria and the formation of oolites and hard grounds, Sedimentology, 48:215-229.</ref> silicate clay minerals,<ref>Folk, RL and Lynch, FL, (1997) The possible role of nanobacteria (dwarf bacteria) in clay-mineral diagenesis, Journal of Sedimentary Research, 67:583-589.</ref> metal sulfides,<ref>Folk, RL (2005) nanobacteria and the formation of framboidal pyrite, Journal Earth System Science, 114:369-374</ref> and iron oxides.<ref>Folk, RL and Carlin J (2006) Adventures in an iron birdbath: nanostructure of iron oxide and the nanobacteria connection, Geological Society of America, Abstracts with programs, v. 38 (3), p. 6.</ref> In all these chemically diverse minerals, the putative nanobacteria are approximately the same size, mainly 0.05 to 0.2 μm. This suggests a commonality of origin. At least for the type locality at Viterbo, Italy, the biogenicity of these minute cells has been supported by transmission electron microscopy (TEM).<ref>Kirkland, B and Lynch, FL (2005) nanobacteria, Big Foot and the Loch Ness Monster—what are you supposed to believe?, Geological Society of America, abs. with progr., v. 37:253.</ref> Slices through a green bioslime showed entities from 0.4 down to as small as 0.09 μm with definite cell walls and interior dots resembling ribosomes; and even smaller objects with cell walls and lucent interiors with diameters of 0.05 μm.<ref>Folk, RL and Kirkland, B, (2007) On the smallness of life: new TEM evidence from biofilm in hot springs, Viterbo, Italy, Geological Society of America, abs. with proper., v. 39 (6) 421.</ref> Culturable organisms on earth are the same 0.05 μm size as the supposed nanobacteria on Mars.<ref>Folk, RL and Taylor, L (2002) nanobacterial alteration of pyroxenes in Martian meteorite ALH84001, Meteorology and Planetary Science, v. 37:1057-1070.</ref>

{{Expand Russian|Пренебрежимое старение|date=September 2017}} [[File:Testudo horsfieldii locking into the camera.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Some tortoises show negligible senescence.]] '''Negligible senescence''' is a term coined by [[biogerontology|biogerontologist]] [[Caleb Finch]] to denote organisms that do not exhibit evidence of [[senescence]] (biological aging), such as measurable reductions in their reproductive capability, measurable functional decline, or rising death rates with age.<ref name=FinchLSG>{{cite book |last1=Finch |first1=Caleb |title=Longevity, Senescence and the Genome |date=1994 |publisher=. University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago, IL |pages=206-247 |chapter=Negligible Senescence}}</ref>
There are many examples of species for whose organisms scientists have not detected an increase in mortality rate after maturity.<ref name=FinchLSG/> This may mean that the lifespan of the organism is so long that researchers' subjects have not yet lived up to the time when a measure of the species' longevity can be made. Turtles, for example, were once thought to lack senescence, but more extensive observations have found evidence of decreasing fitness with age.<ref name=":0" />
Study of negligibly senescent animals may provide clues that lead to better understanding of the aging process<ref name=FinchLSG/><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Guerin | first1 = J | year = 2004 | title = Emerging area of aging research: long-lived animals with "negligible senescence" | url = | journal = Ann N Y Acad Sci | volume = 1019 | issue = | pages = 518–20 | doi=10.1196/annals.1297.096 | pmid=15247078}}</ref> and influence [[evolution of aging|theories of aging]]. The phenomenon of negligible senescence in some animals is a traditional argument for attempting to achieve similar negligible senescence in humans by technological means.
There are also organisms{{which|date=January 2017}} that exhibit negative senescence, whereby mortality chronologically decreases as the organism ages, for all or part of the life cycle, in disagreement with the [[Gompertz–Makeham law of mortality]]<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0262-4079(07)62033-8 |title=Evolution's greatest mistakes |year=2007 |author=Ainsworth, C |journal=New Scientist |volume=195 |pages=36–39 |last2=Lepage |first2=M|issue=2616}}</ref> (see also [[Late-life mortality deceleration]]). Furthermore, there are species that have been observed to regress to a larval state and regrow into adults multiple times, such as ''[[Turritopsis dohrnii]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://8e.devbio.com/preview_article.php?ch=2&id=6 |title=Cheating Death: The Immortal Life Cycle of ''Turritopsis'' |publisher=8e.devbio.com |accessdate=2010-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402085711/http://8e.devbio.com/preview_article.php?ch=2&id=6 |archivedate=2010-04-02 |df= }}</ref>
Recent studies have indicated a connection between phenomena related to negligible senescence and the general stability of an organism's [[genome]], specifically [[transcription (genetics)|transcription]] processes, over its lifetime.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kogan|first1=Valeria|first2=Ivan|last2=Molodtcov|first3=Leonid I.|last3=Menshikov|first4=Robert J.|last4=Shmookler Reis|first5=Peter|last5=Fedichev|title=Stability analysis of a model gene network links aging, stress resistance, and negligible senescence|journal=Scientific Reports|volume=5|year=2015|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep13589|doi=10.1038/srep13589|pages=13589|pmid=26316217|pmc=4551969}}</ref>
==In vertebrates== Some fish, such as some varieties of [[sturgeon]] and [[rougheye rockfish]], and some [[tortoise]]s and [[turtle]]s<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Miller | first1 = J | year = 2001 | title = Escaping senescence: demographic data from the three-toed box turtle (Terrapene carolina triunguis)". | url = | journal = Exp Gerontol | volume = 36 | issue = 4–6| pages = 829–32 | doi=10.1016/s0531-5565(00)00243-6}}</ref> are thought to be negligibly senescent, although recent research on turtles has uncovered evidence of senescence in the wild.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Warner|first=Daniel A.|last2=Miller|first2=David A. W.|last3=Bronikowski|first3=Anne M.|last4=Janzen|first4=Fredric J.|date=2016-06-07|title=Decades of field data reveal that turtles senesce in the wild|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/113/23/6502|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=113|issue=23|pages=6502–6507|doi=10.1073/pnas.1600035113|issn=0027-8424|pmc=4988574|pmid=27140634}}</ref> The age of a captured fish specimen can be measured by examining growth patterns similar to [[tree rings]] on the [[otolith]]s (parts of motion-sensing organs).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bennett | first1 = J | year = 1882 | title = Confirmation on longevity in Sebastes diploproa (pisces Scorpaenidae) from 210Pb/226Ra measurements in otoliths | url = | journal = Maritime Biology | volume = 71 | issue = | pages = 209–215 | doi=10.1007/bf00394632}}</ref>
==In plants== In plants, [[aspen]] trees are one example of [[biological immortality]]. Each individual tree can live for 40–150 years above ground, but the [[root]] system of the [[clonal colony]] is long-lived. In some cases, this is for thousands of years, sending up new trunks as the older trunks die off above ground. One such colony in [[Utah]], given the nickname of [[Pando (Quaking Aspen)|"Pando"]], is estimated to be 80,000 years old, making it possibly the [[list of long-living organisms|oldest living colony]] of aspens.<ref>[http://www.nps.gov/brca/naturescience/quakingaspen.htm Quaking Aspen] by the [[Bryce Canyon]] [[National Park Service]].</ref>
The world's oldest known living non-[[Vegetative cloning|clonal]] organism was the [[Methuselah (tree)|Methuselah tree]] of the species ''[[Pinus longaeva]]'' growing high in the [[White Mountains (California)|White Mountains]] of [[Inyo County, California|Inyo County]] in eastern [[California]], aged {{Age as of date|4789|1957|August|5}} years.<ref name=database>{{cite web |url=http://www.conifers.org/pi/Pinus_longaeva.php |title= ''Pinus longaeva'' |accessdate= 2008-06-20 |publisher= Gymnosperm Database|date= March 15, 2007}}</ref> This record was superseded in 2012 by another Great Basin bristlecone pine located in the same region as Methuselah, and was estimated to be 5062 years old. The tree was sampled by Edmund Schulman and dated by Tom Harlan.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rmtrr.org/oldlist.htm |title=OLDLIST, a database of old trees |last=Brown |first=Peter M |date=2012 |publisher=Rocky Mountain Tree-Ring Research, Inc. |access-date=2017-11-29}}</ref>
==In bacteria== Among [[bacteria]], individual organisms are vulnerable and can easily die, but on the level of the [[Colony (biology)|colony]], bacteria can live indefinitely. The two daughter bacteria resulting from [[cell division]] of a parent bacterium can be regarded as unique individuals or as members of a biologically “immortal” colony.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chao|first=Lin|author2=Guttman, David S.|title=A Model for Damage Load and Its Implications for the Evolution of Bacterial Aging|journal=PLoS Genetics|date=26 August 2010|volume=6|issue=8|pages=e1001076|doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1001076|pmid=20865171|pmc=2928801}}</ref> The two daughter cells can be regarded as “rejuvenated” copies of the parent cell because damaged macromolecules have been split between the two cells and diluted.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rang|first=Camilla U.|author2=Peng, Annie Y. |author3=Chao, Lin |title=Temporal Dynamics of Bacterial Aging and Rejuvenation|journal=Current Biology|date=8 November 2011|volume=21|issue=21|pages=1813–1816|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2011.09.018|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982211010207|pmid=22036179}}</ref> See [[asexual reproduction]].
==Maximum life span== Some examples of maximum observed life span of animals thought to be negligibly senescent are: {| class="wikitable" |- | [[Rougheye rockfish]] || 205 years<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Munk | first1 = K | year = 2001 | title = Maximum Ages of Groundfishes in Waters off Alaska and British Columbia and Considerations of Age Determination | url = | journal = Alaska Fishery Research Bulletin | volume = 8 | issue = | page = 1 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cailliet | first1 = G.M. | last2 = Andrews | first2 = A.H. | last3 = Burton | first3 = E.J. | last4 = Watters | first4 = D.L. | last5 = Kline | first5 = D.E. | last6 = Ferry-Graham | first6 = L.A. | year = 2001 | title = Age determination and validation studies of marine fishes: do deep-dwellers live longer?". | url = | journal = Exp. Gerontol | volume = 36 | issue = | pages = 739–764 | doi=10.1016/s0531-5565(00)00239-4}}</ref> |- | [[Aldabra Giant Tortoise]] || 255 years |- | [[Lobster]]s || 100+ years (presumed)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28589278/ |title=140-year-old lobster's tale has a happy ending. |publisher=Associated Press |date=January 10, 2009}}</ref> |- | [[Hydra (genus)|Hydra]]s || Observed to be [[biologically immortal]]<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.biochem.uci.edu/Steele/PDFs/Hydra_senescence_paper.pdf |title=Mortality patterns suggest lack of senescence in hydras |first=Daniel E |last=Martínez |journal=Experimental Gerontology |volume=33 |number=3 |year=1998 |pages=217–225 |doi=10.1016/s0531-5565(97)00113-7 |pmid=9615920}}</ref> |- | [[Sea anemone]]s || 60–80 years (generally)<ref name="Sea Anemone">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/blueplanet/factfiles/jellies/sea_anemone_bg.shtml|title=Fact Files: Sea anemone|publisher=BBC Science and Nature|accessdate=2009-10-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718221530/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/blueplanet/factfiles/jellies/sea_anemone_bg.shtml|archivedate=2009-07-18|df=}}</ref> |- | [[Freshwater pearl mussel]] || 210–250 years<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ziuganov, V., San Miguel, E., Neves, R.J., Longa, A., Fernandez, C., Amaro, R., Beletsky, V., Popkovitch, E., Kaliuzhin, S., Johnson, T.|year=2000|title=Life span variation of the freshwater pearlshell: a model species for testing longevity mechanisms in animals.|journal=Ambio|volume=ХХIX|issue=2|pages=102–105|doi=10.1579/0044-7447-29.2.102|url=http://pinnacle.allenpress.com/doi/pdf/10.1579/0044-7447-29.2.102}}</ref><ref name=" Зюганов В.В.">{{cite journal|title=Арктические долгоживущие и южные короткоживущие моллюски жемчужницы как модель для изучения основ долголетия.|author=Зюганов В.В.|journal=Успехи геронтол.|volume=14|pages=21–31|year=2004}}</ref> |- | [[Ocean quahog|Ocean Quahog clam]] || 507 years<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Munro | first1 = D. | last2 = Blier | first2 = P.U. | year = 2012 | title = The extreme longevity of Arctica islandica is associated with increased peroxidation resistance in mitochondrial membranes | url = | journal = Aging Cell | volume = 11 | issue = 5| pages = 845–55 | doi = 10.1111/j.1474-9726.2012.00847.x }}</ref> |- | [[Greenland Shark]] || 400 years<ref name="PE2016">{{cite web|last1=Pennisi|first1=Elizabeth|title=Greenland Shark May Live 400 Years, Smashing Longevity Record|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/08/greenland-shark-may-live-400-years-smashing-longevity-record|publisher=Science Magazine|date=11 August 2016}}</ref> |}
==Cryptobiosis== Some rare organisms, such as [[tardigrade]]s, usually have short lifespans, but are able to survive for thousands of years — and, perhaps, indefinitely — if they enter into the state of [[cryptobiosis]], whereby their [[metabolism]] is reversibly suspended. It is hypothesized by advocates of [[cryonics]] that the human [[central nervous system]] can be similarly put into a state of [[suspended animation]] shortly before [[brain death]] to be revived at a future point in the technological development of humankind when such operation would be possible.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Negligible Senescence}} [[Category:Senescence]] [[Category:Biological evolution]] [[Category:Immortality]] [[Category:Negligibly senescent organisms|*]]

'''OpenWorm''' is an international [[open science]] project to simulate the roundworm ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]'' at the cellular level as a [[simulation]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/05/05/nematode_fanciers_open_their_worm_to_a_kickstarter/ |title=What's that PARASITE wriggling inside my browser? Nematode fanciers open their worm to a Kickstarter |work=The Register |date=5 May 2014 |first=Richard |last=Chirgwin}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |first1=Andrey |last1=Palyanov |first2=Sergey |last2=Khayrulin |first3=Stephen D. |last3=Larson |first4=Alexander|last4=Dibert|date=2012-01-01|title=Towards a virtual C. elegans: A framework for simulation and visualization of the neuromuscular system in a 3D physical environment|journal=In Silico Biology|language=en|volume=11|issue=3|doi=10.3233/isb-2012-0445|issn=1386-6338|pmid=22935967|pages=137-147|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Andrey_Palyanov/publication/235326413_Towards_a_virtual_C_Elegans_A_framework_for_simulation_and_visualization_of_the_neuromuscular_system_in_a_3D_physical_environment/links/0912f503d6bcfcbe36000000.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gewaltig|first=Marc-Oliver|last2=Cannon|first2=Robert|date=2014-01-23|title=Current Practice in Software Development for Computational Neuroscience and How to Improve It|url=http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003376|journal=PLOS Computational Biology|language=en|volume=10|issue=1|pages=e1003376|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003376|issn=1553-7358|pmc=3900372|pmid=24465191}}</ref> Although the long-term goal is to model all 959 cells of the ''C. elegans'', the first stage is to model the worm's locomotion by simulating the 302 neurons and 95 muscle cells. This bottom up simulation is being pursued by the OpenWorm community. As of this writing, a physics engine called [[Sibernetic]] has been built for the project and models of the neural [[connectome]] and a muscle cell have been created in [[NeuroML]] format. A 3D model of the worm anatomy can be accessed through the web via the OpenWorm browser. The OpenWorm project is also contributing to develop Geppetto,<ref>[http://www.geppetto.org Geppetto]</ref> a web-based multi-algorithm, multi-scale simulation platform engineered to support the simulation of the whole organism.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/04/30/openworm-is-going-to-be-a-digital-organism-in-your-browser/ |title=Openworm is going to be a digital organism in your browser |date=30 April 2014 |last=Takahashi |first=Dean |work=VentureBeat}}</ref>
__TOC__
== Background: ''C. elegans'' == The roundworm ''C. elegans'' has one of the simplest nervous systems of any organism, with its [[hermaphrodite]] type having only 302 neurons. Furthermore, the structural [[connectome]] of these neurons is fully worked out. There are fewer than one thousand cells in the whole body of a ''C. elegans'' worm, and because ''C. Elegans'' is a [[model organism]], each has a unique identifier and comprehensive supporting literature. Being a model organism, the genome is fully known, along with many well characterized mutants readily available, a comprehensive literature of behavioural studies, etc. With so few neurons and new calcium 2 photon microscopy techniques it should soon be possible to record the complete neural activity of a living organism. By manipulating the neurons through optogenetic techniques, combined with the above recording capacities the project is in an unprecedented position to be able to fully characterize the neural dynamics of an entire organism.
In the process of trying to build an "in silico" model of a relatively simple organism like ''C. elegans'', new tools are being developed which will make it easier to model progressively more complex organisms.
===NemaLoad===
Project Nemaload <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20121007022842/http://nemaload.davidad.org/ NemaLoad]</ref> was created as a research program trying to empirically establish the relevant biological facts which are necessary for a true bottom-up simulation. The project founder, [[David Dalrymple (computer scientist)|David Dalrymple]], is a collaborator on the OpenWorm project.
==OpenWorm project==
Although the ultimate goal is to simulate all features of ''C. elegans''' behaviour, the project is new and the first behaviour the Open Worm community decided to simulate is a simple motor response: teaching the worm to crawl. To do so, the virtual worm must be placed in a virtual environment. A full feedback loop must be established: Environmental Stimulus > Sensory Transduction > Interneuron Firing > Motor Neuron Firing > Motor Output > Environmental Change > Sensory Transduction.
There are two main technical challenges here: modelling the neural/electrical properties of the brain as it processes the information, and modelling the mechanical properties of the body as it moves. The neural properties are being modeled by a [[Hodgkin-Huxley model]], and the mechanical properties are being modeled by a Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamic algorithm.
The OpenWorm team built an engine called Geppetto which could integrate these algorithms and due to its modularity will be able to model other biological systems (like [[digestion]]) which the team will tackle at a later time.
The team also built an environment called NeuroConstruct which is able to output neural structures in [[NeuroML]]. Using NeuroConstruct the team reconstructed the full connectome of ''C. elegans''.
Using NeuroML the team has also built a model of a muscle cell. Note that these models currently only model the relevant properties for the simple motor response: the neural/electrical and the mechanical properties discussed above.
The next step is to connect this muscle cell to the six neurons which synapse on it and approximate their effect.
The rough plan is to then both: * Approximate the synapses which synapse on those neurons * Repeat the process for other muscle cells
===Progress=== As of January 2015, the project is still awaiting peer review, and researchers involved in the project are reluctant to make bold claims about its current resemblance to biological behavior; project coordinator Stephen Larson estimates that they are "only 20 to 30 percent of the way towards where we need to get".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/01/21/tech/mci-lego-worm/ |title=Scientists upload a worm's mind into a Lego robot |work=CNN |last=Shadbolt |first=Peter |date=21 January 2015}}</ref>
== Related projects ==
In 1998 Japanese researchers announced the Perfect C. elegans Project. A proposal was submitted, but the project appears to have been abandoned.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kitano|first=Hiroaki|last2=Hamahashi|first2=Shugo|last3=Luke|first3=Sean|date=April 1998|title=The Perfect C. ELEGANS Project: An Initial Report|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hiroaki_Kitano2/publication/13441177_The_Perfect_C_elegans_Project_An_Initial_Report/links/54b00d4d0cf220c63ccdd986.pdf|journal=Artificial Life|language=en|volume=4|issue=2|pages=141–156|doi=10.1162/106454698568495|issn=1064-5462}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jefftk.com/p/whole-brain-emulation-and-nematodes |title=Whole brain emulation and nematodes |last=Kaufman |first=Jeff |date=2 November 2011}}</ref>
In 2004 a group from Hiroshima began the Virtual C. elegans Project. They released two papers which showed how their simulation would retract from virtual prodding.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.bsys.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/pub/pdf/J/J_152.pdf |title=A dynamic body model of the Nematode C. elegans with neural oscillators |journal=Journal of Robotics and Mechatronics |volume=17 |issue=3 |date=2005 |first1=Michiyo |last1=Suzuki |first2=Takeshi |last2=Goto |first3=Toshio |last3=Tsuji |first4=Hisao |last4=Ohtake |pages=318–326}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Suzuki|first=Michiyo|last2=Tsuji|first2=Toshio|last3=Ohtake|first3=Hisao|date=September 2005|title=A model of motor control of the nematode C. elegans with neuronal circuits|url=http://www.bsys.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/pub/pdf/J/J_153.pdf|journal=Artificial Intelligence in Medicine|volume=35|issue=1-2|pages=75–86|doi=10.1016/j.artmed.2005.01.008|issn=0933-3657}}</ref>
In 2005 a Texas researcher described a simplified C. elegans simulator based on a 1-wire network incorporating a digital Parallax Basic Stamp processor, sensory inputs and motor outputs. Inputs employed 16-bit A/D converters attached to operational amplifier simulated neurons and a 1-wire temperature sensor. Motor outputs were controlled by 256-position digital potentiometers and 8-bit digital ports. Artificial muscle action was based on Nitinol actuators. It used a "sense-process-react" operating loop which recreated several instinctual behaviors.<ref>{{cite conference |first=Paul |last=Frenger |title=Simple C. elegans Nervous System Emulator |conference=Houston Conference for Biomedical Engineering Research |date=2005 |page=192}}</ref>
These early attempts of simulation have been criticized for not being biologically realistic. Although we have the complete structural connectome, we do not know the [[synaptic weight]]s at each of the known synapses. We do not even know whether the synapses are inhibitory or excitatory. To compensate for this the Hiroshima group used machine learning to find some weights of the synapses which would generate the desired behaviour. It is therefore no surprise that the model displayed the behaviour, and it may not represent true understanding of the system.
==Open science== The Open Worm community is committed to the ideals of [[open science]]. Generally this means that the team will try to publish in open access journals and include all data gathered (to avoid the file drawer problem). Indeed, all the biological data the team has gathered is publicly available, and the five publications the group has made so far are available for free on their website. All the software that OpenWorm has produced is completely free and open source.
Open Worm is also trying a radically open model of scientific collaboration. The team consists of anyone who wishes to be a part of it. There are over one hundred "members" who are signed up for the high volume technical mailing list. Of the most active members who are named on a publication there are collaborators from Russia, Brazil, England, Scotland, Ireland and the United States. To coordinate this international effort, the team uses "virtual lab meetings" and other online tools that are detailed in the resources section.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * Homepage: [http://www.openworm.org/ Openworm] * [http://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!forum/openworm-discuss OpenWorm community] * [https://github.com/openworm/OpenWorm/milestones Milestones]. * [http://www.sibernetic.org Sibernetic] * [http://www.openworm.org/downloads.html Models] * [http://browser.openworm.org/ OpenWorm browser] * [http://www.geppetto.org Geppetto]
