revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Philosophy sidebar}} The '''philosophy of happiness''' is the [[philosophical]] concern with the [[existence]], [[nature]], and attainment of [[happiness]]. Philosophers believe, happiness can be understood as the moral goal of life or as an aspect of chance; indeed, in most European languages the term happiness is synonymous with luck.Cassin et al. ''Dictionary of Untranslatables''. Princeton University Press, 2014. Print. Thus, philosophers usually explicate on happiness as either a state of mind, or a life that goes well for the person leading it.{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/happiness/#MeaHap|title=Happiness|work=stanford.edu}} ==Ancient Greece== ===Plato=== {{rquote|right|''We have proved that justice in itself is the best thing for the soul itself, and that the soul ought to do justice...''|[[Plato]], ''[[The Republic (Plato)|The Republic]]''Plato, ''The Republic'' 10.612b}} [[Plato]] (c. 428{{snd}} c. 347 BCE), using [[Socrates]] (c. 470{{snd}} 399 BCE) as the main character in his [[Plato#The dialogues|philosophical dialogues]], outlined the requirements for happiness in ''The Republic''. In ''[[The Republic (Plato)|The Republic]]'', Plato asserts that those who are moral are the only ones who may be truly happy. Thus, one must understand the [[cardinal virtues]], particularly justice. Through the thought experiment of the [[Ring of Gyges]], Plato comes to the conclusion that one who abuses power enslaves himself to his appetites, while the man who chooses not to remains rationally in control of himself, and therefore is happy.[https://www.academia.edu/12487162/Plato_Happiness_and_Justice Joshua Olsen, ''Plato, Happiness and Justice''] He also sees a type of happiness stemming from [[social justice]] through fulfilling one's social function; since this duty forms happiness, other typically seen sources of happiness{{snd}} such as leisure, wealth, and pleasure{{snd}} are deemed lesser, if not completely false, forms of happiness.[https://www.jstor.org/stable/27743804 Richard D. Mohr, "A Platonic Happiness". ''History of Philosophy Quarterly,'' Vol. 4, No. 2 (Apr., 1987), pp. 131-145.University of Illinois.] ===Aristotle=== [[Aristotle]] (384 – 322 BCE) held that ''[[eudaimonia]]'' ([[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: [[:Wiktionary:εὐδαιμονία|εὐδαιμονία]]) is the goal of human thought and action. Eudaimonia is usually translated as [[happiness]], but "human flourishing" may be a more accurate translation.Daniel N. Robinson. (1999). Aristotle's Psychology. Published by Daniel N. Robinson. {{ISBN|0-9672066-0-X}} {{ISBN|978-0967206608}} Eudaimonia involves activity, exhibiting virtue (''[[arete (moral virtue)|arete]]'', [[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: [[wiktionary:ἀρετή|ἀρετή]]) in accordance with [[virtue]]. Within the ''[[Nicomachean Ethics]]'', Aristotle points to the fact that many aims are really only intermediate aims, and are desired only because they make the achievement of higher aims possible.Book I Chapter 1 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0054%3Abekker+page%3D1094a 1094a]. Therefore, things such as wealth, intelligence, and courage are valued only in relation to other things, while eudaimonia is the only thing valuable in isolation. Aristotle regarded virtue as necessary for a person to be happy and held that without virtue the most that may be attained is contentment. Aristotle has been criticized for failing to show that virtue is necessary in the way he claims it to be, and he does not address this moral skepticism.Kraut, Richard, "Aristotle's Ethics", The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2012 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.), URL = ===Cynicism=== {{Main|Cynicism (philosophy)}} [[File:Greek philosopher busts.jpg|thumb|The carved busts of [[Socrates]], [[Antisthenes]], [[Chrysippus]], and [[Epicurus]].]] [[Antisthenes]] (c. 445 – c. 365 BCE), often regarded as the founder of [[Cynicism (philosophy)|Cynicism]], advocated an ascetic life lived in accordance with [[virtue]]. Xenophon testifies that Antisthenes had praised the joy that sprang "from out of one's soul,"Xenophon, Symposium, iv. 41. and [[Diogenes Laertius]] relates that Antisthenes was fond of saying: "I would rather go mad than feel pleasure."[[Diogenes Laërtius]], ''[[Lives and Opinions of Eminent Philosophers]]'', vi. 3 He maintained that virtue was sufficient in itself to ensure happiness, only needing the strength of a [[Socrates]]. He, along with all following Cynics, rejected any conventional notions of happiness involving money, [[power (sociology)|power]], and [[celebrity|fame]], to lead entirely virtuous, and thus happy, [[personal life|lives]].[http://www.iep.utm.edu/c/cynics.htm ''Cynics''] – ''The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy'' Thus, happiness can be gained through [[asceticism|rigorous training]] (askesis, [[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: [[:Wiktionary:ἄσκησις|ἄσκησις]]) and by living in a way which was natural for [[humans]], rejecting all conventional desires, preferring a [[simple living|simple life]] free from all possessions. [[Diogenes of Sinope]] (c. 412 – c. 323 BCE) is most frequently seen as the perfect embodiment of the philosophy. The [[stoicism|Stoics]] themselves saw him as one of the few, if not only, who have had achieved the state of [[sophos (philosophy)|sage]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ancientworlds.net/aw/Article/497576|title=The Stoic Sage|work=ancientworlds.net}} ===Stoicism=== {{Main|Stoicism}} {{rquote|right|''If you work at that which is before you, following right reason seriously, vigorously, calmly, without allowing anything else to distract you, but keeping your divine part pure, as if you were bound to give it back immediately; if you hold to this, expecting nothing, but satisfied to live now according to nature, speaking heroic truth in every word that you utter, you will live happy. And there is no man able to prevent this.''|[[Marcus Aurelius]], ''[[Meditations]]''[[Marcus Aurelius]], ''[[Meditations]]''. iii.12}} [[Stoicism]] was a school of philosophy established by [[Zeno of Citium]] (c. 334 – c. 262 BCE). While Zeno was [[syncretism|syncretic]] in thought, his primary influence were the Cynics, with [[Crates of Thebes]] (c. 365 – c. 285 BCE) as his mentor. Stoics believe that "virtue is sufficient for [[happiness]]".[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/stoicism/ Stoicism], Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. One who has attained this sense of virtue would become a [[sage (philosophy)|sage]]. In the words of Epictetus, this sage would be "sick and yet happy, in peril and yet happy, dying and yet happy, in exile and happy, in disgrace and happy,"Russell, Bertrand. ''A History of Western Philosophy'' The Stoics therefore spent their time trying to attain virtue. This would only be achieved if one was to dedicate their life studying [[Stoic logic]], [[Stoic physics]], and [[Stoicism#Ethics and virtues|Stoic ethics]]. ===Cyrenaics=== {{Main|Cyrenaics}} {{rquote|right|''As a consequence the [[sage (philosophy)|sage]], even if he has his troubles, will nonetheless be happy, even if few pleasures accrue to him.''|[[Diogenes Laertius]] on [[Anniceris]][[Diogenes Laërtius]], ''[[Lives and Opinions of Eminent Philosophers]]'', ii. 96-97Diogenes the Cynics: Sayings and Anecdotes with Other Popular Moralists, trans. Robin Hard. Oxford University Press, 2012. Page 152.}} The [[Cyrenaics]] were a school of philosophy established by [[Aristippus of Cyrene]] (c. 435 – c. 356 BCE). The school asserted that the only good is positive pleasure, and pain is the only evil. They posit that all feeling is momentary so all past and future pleasure have no real existence for an individual, and that among present pleasures there is no distinction of kind.{{Harvnb|Annas|1995|p=230}} [[Claudius Aelianus]], in his ''Historical Miscellany'',Aelian, Historical Miscellany 14.6 writes about Aristippus: {{quote|"He recommended that one should concrete on the present day, and indeed on the very part of it in which one is acting and thinking. For only the present, he said, truly belongs to us, and not what has passed by or what we are anticipating: for the one is gone and done with, and it is uncertain whether the other will come to be"Diogenes the Cynics: Sayings and Anecdotes with Other Popular Moralists, trans. Robin Hard. Oxford University Press, 2012. Page 124.}} Some immediate pleasures can create more than their equivalent of pain. The wise person should be in control of pleasures rather than be enslaved to them, otherwise pain will result, and this requires judgement to evaluate the different pleasures of life.{{Harvnb|Copleston|2003|p=122}} ===Epicureanism=== {{Main|Epicureanism}} {{rquote|right|''Of all the means which wisdom acquires to ensure happiness throughout the whole of life, by far the most important is friendship.''|Epicurus{{cite web|url=http://www.epicurus.net/en/principal.html|title=Epicurus - Principal Doctrines|author=Vincent Cook|work=epicurus.net}}}} [[Epicureanism]] was founded by [[Epicurus]] (c. 341 – c. 270 BCE). The goal of his philosophy was to attain a state of [[ataraxia|tranquility]] (''ataraxia'', [[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: [[:Wiktionary:ἀταραξία|ἀταραξία]]) and freedom from fear, as well as [[aponia|absence of bodily pain]] (''aponia'', [[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: [[:Wiktionary: ἀπονία|ἀπονία]]). Toward these ends, Epicurus recommended an [[asceticism|ascetic lifestyle]], noble friendship, and the avoidance of politics. One aid to achieving happiness is the ''[[tetrapharmakos]]'' or the four-fold cure: [[File:Tetrapharmakos PHerc 1005 col 5.png|250px|thumb|A [[papyrus]] copy depicting the Epicurean [[tetrapharmakos]] in [[Philodemus of Gadara]]'s ''Adversus Sophistas'' - [[Herculaneum papyri|(P.Herc.1005), col. 5]]]]
"Do not fear [[god]],
Do not worry about [[death]];
What is [[good and evil|good]] is easy to get, and
What is terrible is easy to [[endurance|endure]]."
(''[[Philodemus]], [[Herculaneum Papyrus]], 1005, 4.9–14'').{{cite book|last =Hutchinson|first =D. S. (Introduction)|title =The Epicurus Reader: Selected Writings and Testimonia|publisher =Cambridge: Hackett|year =1994|page =vi}}
==Ancient Rome== ===School of the Sextii=== {{Main|School of the Sextii}} The School of the Sextii was founded by [[Quintus Sextius the Elder]] ([[fl.]] 50 BCE). It characterized itself mainly as a philosophical-medical school, blending [[Pythagoreanism|Pythagorean]], [[Platonism|Platonic]], [[Cynicism (philosophy)|Cynic]], and [[Stoicism|Stoic]] elements together.{{cite web|url=http://www.ricercafilosofica.it/epekeina/index.php/epekeina/article/view/74|title=Philosophical thought of the School of the Sextii - Di Paola - EPEKEINA. International Journal of Ontology. History and Critics|work=ricercafilosofica.it}} They argued that to achieve happiness, one ought to be vegetarian, have nightly examinations of conscience, and avoid both [[consumerism]] and [[politics]],Emily Wilson, ''The Greatest Empire: A Life of Seneca''. Oxford University Press, 2014. p.54-55 and believe that an elusive incorporeal power pervades the body. ===Augustine of Hippo=== {{rquote|right|''Nevertheless, to praise you is the desire of man, a little piece of your creation. You stir man to take pleasure in praising you, because you have made us for yourself, and our heart is restless until it rests in you.''|St. Augustine, ''[[Confessions (St. Augustine)|Confessions]]''.St. Augustine, ''Confessions''. Trans, Henry Chadwick. Oxford University Press, 2008. p:3}} {{rquote|right|''The happy life is joy based on the truth. This is joy grounded in you, O God, who are the truth.''|St. Augustine, ''[[Confessions (St. Augustine)|Confessions]]''.St. Augustine, ''Confessions''. Trans, Henry Chadwick. Oxford University Press, 2008. p:199}} [[St. Augustine of Hippo]] (354 – 430 AD) was an early [[Christian theology|Christian theologian]] and [[philosopher]]{{cite encyclopedia|last=Mendelson|first=Michael|title=Saint Augustine|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2012/entries/augustine/|publisher=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|accessdate=21 December 2012}} whose writings influenced the development of [[Western Christianity]] and [[Western philosophy]]. For St. Augustine, all human actions revolve around [[love]], and the primary problem humans face is the misplacing of love.https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/ethics-everyone/201106/achieving-hapGenesis creation narrativepiness-advice-augustine Only in [[God]] can one find happiness, as He is source of happiness. Since [[Genesis creation narrative|humanity was brought forth from God]], but has [[Fall of man|since fallen]], one's [[soul]] dimly remembers the happiness from when one was with God.[https://www.jstor.org/stable/1582804 R. J. O'Connell, "The Enneads and St. Augustine's Image of Happiness." ''Vigiliae Christianae'' Vol. 17, No. 3 (Sep., 1963)] Thus, if one orients themselves toward the love of God, all other loves will become properly ordered.{{cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/ethics-everyone/201106/achieving-happiness-advice-augustine|title=Achieving Happiness: Advice from Augustine|work=Psychology Today}} In this manner, St. Augustine follows the [[Neoplatonic]] tradition in asserting that happiness lays in the contemplation of the purely intelligible realm. St. Augustine deals with the concept of happiness directly in his treatises ''De beata vita'' and ''Contra Academicos''. ===Boethius=== {{rquote|right|''Mortal creatures have one overall concern. This they work at by toiling over a whole range of pursuits, advancing on different paths, but striving to attain the one goal of happiness.''|[[Boethius]], ''[[The Consolation of Philosophy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.com/magazine/articles/true-happiness-and-the-consolation-of-philosophy|title=True Happiness and The Consolation of Philosophy|work=catholic.com}}}} [[Boethius]] (c. 480–524 AD) was a [[philosopher]], most famous for writing ''[[The Consolation of Philosophy]]''. The work has been described as having had the single most important influence on the [[Christianity]] [[History of Christianity during the Middle Ages|of the Middle Ages and]] early [[The Renaissance|Renaissance]] and as the last great work of the [[Classical antiquity|Classical Period]].Introduction to ''The Consolation of Philosophy'', Oxford World's Classics, 2000.[[Dante Alighieri|Dante]] identified Boethius as the "last of the Romans and first of the Scholastics" among the doctors in his Paradise (see ''[[The Divine Comedy]]'' and also below). The book describes many themes, but among them he discusses how happiness can be attainable despite changing [[Luck|fortune]], while considering the nature of happiness and God. He posits that happiness is acquired by attaining the perfect good, and that perfect good is God. He then concludes that as God ruled the universe through Love, prayer to God and the application of Love would lead to true happiness.Sanderson Beck (1996). ==Middle Ages== ===Avicenna=== [[File:Avicenna Drawing.jpg|thumb|100px|right|A drawing of Avicenna, 1960.]] [[Avicenna]] (c. 980–1037), also known as 'Ibn-Sina', was [[polymath]] and [[jurist]]; he is regarded as one of the most significant thinkers in the [[Islamic Golden Age]].{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/45755/Avicenna |title=Avicenna (Persian philosopher and scientist) - Britannica Online Encyclopedia |publisher=Britannica.com |accessdate=2012-01-07}} According to him, happiness is the aim of humans, and that real happiness is pure and free from worldly interest.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oNXfvBjqKZYC&pg=PA208&lpg=PA208&dq=avicenna+happiness&source=bl&ots=CxFa-Nalxz&sig=4tkYaKJRsHudESjmxQGlSP-LY9g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwATgKahUKEwjmxoGx_aHIAhXIcT4KHWLNC7M#v=onepage&q=avicenna%20happiness&f=false|title=International Handbook of Inter-religious Education|work=google.ca}} Ultimately, happiness is reached through the conjunction of the human intellect with the separate active intellect.{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/arabic-islamic-influence/|title=Influence of Arabic and Islamic Philosophy on the Latin West|work=stanford.edu}} ===Al-Ghazali=== {{Main|Kimiya-yi sa'ādat}} [[Al-Ghazali]] (c. 1058–1111) was a [[Muslim]] [[theologian]], [[jurist]], [[philosopher]], and [[mysticism|mystic]] of [[Persian people|Persian]] descent.{{cite web|title=Ghazali, al-|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/al-Ghazali.aspx|work=The Columbia Encyclopedia|accessdate=17 December 2012}} Produced near the end of his life, al-Ghazali wrote ''[[The Alchemy of Happiness]]'' (''Kimiya-yi Sa'ādat'', ({{lang-fa|كيمياى سعادت}}).Bowering, Gerhard. "[Untitled]." Rev. of The Alchemy of Happiness Translated by Claud Feild and Revised by Elton L. Daniel. Journal of Near Eastern Studies July 1995: 227-28. Print In the work, he emphasizes the importance of observing the ritual requirements of [[Islam]], the actions that would lead to salvation, and the avoidance of sin. Only by exercising the human faculty of reason - a God-given ability - can one transform the [[soul]] from worldliness to complete devotion to God, the ultimate happiness.Bodman Jr., Herbert L. "(untitled)." Rev. of The Alchemy of Happiness Translated by Claud Feild and Revised by Elton L. Daniel. Journal of World History Fall 1993: 336-38. Print. According to Al-Ghazali, there are four main constituents of happiness: self-knowledge, knowledge of God, knowledge of this world as it really is, and the knowledge of the next world as it really is.{{cite web|url=http://www.sunnah.org/tasawwuf/alchemy.htm|title=The Alchemy of Happiness|author=Imam Muhammad Al-Ghazali|year=1910|accessdate=8 January 2016}}{{PD-notice}} ===Maimonides=== [[Maimonides]] (c. 1135-1204) was a [[Jewish philosophy|Jewish philosopher]] and [[astronomer]],Maimonides: Abū ʿImrān Mūsā [Moses] ibn ʿUbayd Allāh [Maymūn] al‐Qurṭubī [http://islamsci.mcgill.ca/RASI/BEA/Maimonides_BEA.htm] who became one of the most prolific and influential [[Torah]] scholars and physicians.[http://www.med.uottawa.ca/historyofmedicine/hetenyi/levinoff.htm A Biographical and Historiographical Critique of Moses Maimonides] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524172551/http://www.med.uottawa.ca/historyofmedicine/hetenyi/levinoff.htm |date=24 May 2013 }} He writes that happiness is ultimately and essentially intellectual.{{cite web|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/maimonid/|title=Maimonides - Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|work=utm.edu}} ===Thomas Aquinas=== {{Main|Summa Theologica}} {{rquote|right|''God is happiness by His Essence: for He is happy not by acquisition or participation of something else, but by His Essence.''|[[St. Thomas Aquinas]], ''[[Summa Theologica]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/chr/aquinas/summa/sum136.htm|title=Summa Theologica: Treatise On The Last End (QQ[1]-5): Question. 3 - WHAT IS HAPPINESS (EIGHT ARTICLES)|work=sacred-texts.com}}}} [[St. Thomas Aquinas]] (1225 – 1274 AD) was a [[philosopher]] and [[theologian]], who became a [[Doctor of the Church]] in 1323.{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=2530|title=St. Thomas Aquinas|author=Catholic Online|work=catholic.org}} His system [[syncreticism|syncretized]] [[Aristotelianism]] and [[Catholic theology]] within his ''[[Summa Theologica]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/aq-moral/|title=Aquinas: Moral Philosophy - Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|work=utm.edu}} The first part of the second part is divided into 114 articles, the first five deal explicitly with the happiness of humans.{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/chr/aquinas/summa/|title=Summa Theologica|work=sacred-texts.com}} He states that happiness is achieved by cultivating several intellectual and moral virtues, which enable us to understand the nature of happiness and motivate us to seek it in a reliable and consistent way. Yet, one will be unable to find the greatest happiness in this life, because final happiness consists in [[beatific vision|a supernatural union with God]].''[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2002.htm#8 ST]'', I-II, Q. 2, art. 8. As such, man’s happiness does not consist of wealth, status, pleasure, or in any created good at all. Most goods do not have a necessary connection to happiness, since the ultimate object of man’s will, can only be found in God, who is the source of all good.{{cite web|url=http://www.sparknotes.com/philosophy/aquinas/section4.rhtml|title=SparkNotes: Thomas Aquinas (c. 1225–1274): Summa Theologica: The Purpose of Man|work=sparknotes.com}} ==Early Modern== === Michel de Montaigne === [[Michel de Montaigne]] (1533-1592) was a [[French philosophy|French philosopher]]. Influenced by [[Aristotelianism]] and [[Christianity]], alongside the conviction of the separation of public and private spheres of life, Montaigne writes that happiness is a subjective state of mind and that satisfaction differs from person to person.{{cite web|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/montaign/|title=Montaigne, Michel de - Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|work=utm.edu}} He continues by acknowledging that one must be allowed a private sphere of life to realize those particular attempts of happiness without the interference of society. ===Jeremy Bentham=== {{Main|Utilitarianism}} [[Jeremy Bentham]] (1748-1832) was a British [[philosopher]], [[jurist]], and [[social reformer]]. He is regarded as the founder of modern [[utilitarianism]]. His particular brand of utilitarianism indicated that the most moral action is that which causes the highest amount of utility, where defined utility as the aggregate pleasure after deducting suffering of all involved in any action. Happiness, therefore, is the experience of pleasure and the lack of pain.{{cite web|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/bentham/|title=Bentham, Jeremy - Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|work=utm.edu}} Actions which do not promote the greatest happiness is morally wrong - such as ascetic sacrifice. This manner of thinking permits the possibility of [[Felicific calculus|a calculator to measure happiness and moral value]]. ===Arthur Schopenhauer=== [[Arthur Schopenhauer]] (1788-1860) was a [[Germans|German]] [[philosopher]]. His philosophy express that egotistical acts are those that are guided by self-interest, desire for pleasure or happiness, where as only [[compassion]] can be a moral act. Schopenhauer explains happiness in terms of a wish that is satisfied, which in turn gives rise to a new wish. And the absence of satisfaction is suffering, which results in an empty longing. He also links happiness with the movement of time, as we feel happy when times moves faster and feel sad when time slows down.Arthur Schopenhauer, The World as Will and Idea. Cologne 1997, Volume One, §52th. ==Contemporary== ===Władysław Tatarkiewicz=== [[Władysław Tatarkiewicz]] (1886-1980) was a [[Poland|Polish]] [[philosopher]], historian of [[philosophy]], historian of [[art]], [[esthetics|esthetician]], and [[ethics|ethicist]]."Władysław Tatarkiewicz," ''[[Encyklopedia Polski]]'', p. 686. For Tatarkiewicz, happiness is a fundamental ethical category. ===Herbert Marcuse=== [[Herbert Marcuse]] (1898–1979) was a German-American [[philosophy|philosopher]], [[sociology|sociologist]], and [[political philosophy|political theorist]], associated with the [[Frankfurt School]] of [[critical theory]]. In his 1937 essay 'The Affirmative Character of Culture,' he suggests culture develops tension within the structure of society, and in that tension can challenge the current social order. If it separates itself from the everyday world, the demand for happiness will cease to be external, and begin to become an object of spiritual contemplation.{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/marcuse/|title=Herbert Marcuse|work=stanford.edu}} In the ''[[One-Dimensional Man]]'', his criticism of consumerism suggests that the current system is one that claims to be [[democracy|democratic]], but is [[authoritarian]] in character, as only a few individuals dictate the perceptions of freedom by only allowing certain choices of happiness to be available for purchase.{{cite book | last1 = Marcuse | first1 = Herbert | title = One-dimensional Man: studies in ideology of advanced industrial society | chapter = Introduction to the Second Edition | publisher = Routledge | year = 1991 | location = London | pages = 3 | isbn = 978-0-415-07429-2}} He further suggests that the conception that 'happiness can be bought' is one that is psychologically damaging. ===Viktor Frankl=== {{Main|Logotherapy}} {{Main|Man's Search for Meaning}} {{rquote|right|''It is a characteristic of the American culture that, again and again, one is commanded and ordered to 'be happy.' But happiness cannot be pursued; it must ensue. One must have a reason to 'be happy'.''|[[Viktor Frankl]]{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/a-lesson-about-happiness-from-a-holocaust-survivor-2014-10|title=A Lesson About Happiness From A Holocaust Survivor - Business Insider|date=22 October 2014|work=Business Insider}}}} [[Viktor Frankl]] (1905-1997) was an [[Austrians|Austrian]] [[neurology|neurologist]], [[psychiatry|psychiatrist]], [[Holocaust]] [[List of Holocaust survivors|survivor]] and founder of [[logotherapy]]. His philosophy revolved around the emphasis on meaning, the value of suffering, and responsibility to something greater than the self;http://www.businessinsider.com/a-lesson-about-happiness-from-a-holocaust-survivor-2014-10 only if one encounters those questions can one be happy. ===Robert Nozick=== {{Main|Experience machine}} [[Robert Nozick]] (1938-2002) was an [[United States|American]] [[philosopher]].{{cite web|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/nozick/ |title=Nozick, Robert |work=[[Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] |first=Edward |last=Feser |date=4 May 2005}} In his 1974 book, ''[[Anarchy, State, Utopia]]'', he proposed a thought experiment where one is given the option to enter a machine that would give the maximum amount of unending hedonistic pleasure for the entirety of one's life. ===Scientism=== [[File:World happiness 2006.png|thumb|300px|The [[Satisfaction with Life Index]]]] [[Scientism]] is the approach that the [[empirical sciences]] are the most valuable branches of learning and culture. ===Happiness economics=== [[Happiness economics]] is the quantitative and theoretical study of [[happiness]], positive and negative [[Affect (psychology)|affect]], [[well-being]], [[quality of life]], [[life satisfaction]] and related concepts, typically combining [[economics]] with other fields such as [[psychology]] and [[sociology]]. The tracking of [[Gross National Happiness]] or the [[Satisfaction with Life Index|satisfaction of life]] grow increasingly popular as the economics of happiness challenges traditional economic aims.[[Richard Layard]], 2006. "Happiness and Public Policy: A Challenge to the Profession," ''Economic Journal'', 116(510), Conference Papers, pp. [http://www.staff.ncl.ac.uk/david.harvey/MKT3008/Poverty/Layard2006.pdf C24-C33.] [[Richard Layard]] has been very influential in this area. He has shown that mental illness is the main cause of unhappiness.https://www.amazon.co.uk/Happiness-Lessons-New-Science-Second-ebook/dp/B004TRQAS6/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1521575888&sr=1-3&keywords=richard+layard ===Sonja Lyubomirsky=== [[Sonja Lyubomirsky]] asserted in her 2007 book, ''The How of Happiness'', that happiness is 50 percent genetically determined (based on twin studies),Sonja Lyubomirsky, David Schkade and Kennon M. Sheldon, [http://www.psych.umn.edu/courses/fall06/macdonalda/psy4960/Readings/LyubomirskySustain_RGP05.pdf "Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change,"] Review of General Psychology, Vol. 9, No. 2, 111–131, 2005 10 percent circumstancial, and 40 percent subject to [[self-control]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/21197|title=Are You Happy? by Sue Halpern|work=nybooks.com}}http://us.penguingroup.com/nf/Book/BookDisplay/0,,9781594201486,00.html{{cite web|url=http://www.pe.com/localnews/highereducation/stories/PE_News_Local_D_happy19.3d48c86.html|title=News : Press Enterprise|work=pe.com}} Lyubomirsky suggests a twelve-point program to maximize the final 40 percent. ==Cultures not seeking to maximise happiness== Not all cultures seek to maximise happiness,{{Cite journal | doi=10.1177/0956797618768058| pmid=29889603|title = How Much is Enough in a Perfect World? Cultural Variation in Ideal Levels of Happiness, Pleasure, Freedom, Health, Self-Esteem, Longevity, and Intelligence| journal=Psychological Science| volume=29| issue=9| pages=1393–1404|year = 2018|last1 = Hornsey|first1 = Matthew J.| last2=Bain| first2=Paul G.| last3=Harris| first3=Emily A.| last4=Lebedeva| first4=Nadezhda| last5=Kashima| first5=Emiko S.| last6=Guan| first6=Yanjun| last7=González| first7=Roberto| last8=Chen| first8=Sylvia Xiaohua| last9=Blumen| first9=Sheyla| url=http://dro.dur.ac.uk/24174/1/24174.pdf| type=Submitted manuscript}}See the work of [[Jeanne Tsai]]See [[Life,_Liberty_and_the_pursuit_of_Happiness#Meaning_of_"happiness"]] ref. the meaning of the US Declaration of Independence phrase and some cultures are averse to happiness.{{Cite journal | doi=10.1007/s10902-013-9489-9|title = Aversion to Happiness Across Cultures: A Review of Where and Why People are Averse to Happiness| journal=Journal of Happiness Studies| volume=15| issue=3| pages=717–735|year = 2014|last1 = Joshanloo|first1 = Mohsen| last2=Weijers| first2=Dan}}{{cite web | url=https://phys.org/news/2014-03-cultures-differ-happiness-beliefs.html | title=Study sheds light on how cultures differ in their happiness beliefs}}Also June Gruber http://www.gruberpeplab.com/people.php#director suggests that seeking happiness can have negative effects, such as failed over-high expectations, http://gruberpeplab.com/research.php and instead advocates a more open stance to all emotions. https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2018/jul/20/the-dark-side-of-happiness-science-weekly-podcast Other research has analysed possible trade-offs between happiness and meaning in life.https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17439760.2013.830764 https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17439760.2015.1117129?src=recsys https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/beautiful-minds/the-differences-between-happiness-and-meaning-in-life/ ==See also== [[File:Hendrik ter Brugghen - Democritus.jpg|thumb|200px|upright|''Democritus'' by [[Hendrick ter Brugghen]], 1628.

[[Democritus]] is known as the ‘laughing philosopher’ because of his emphasis on the value of ‘cheerfulness.’{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/democritus/|title=Democritus|work=stanford.edu}}]] {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Happiness]] *[[Eudaimonia]] *[[Religion and happiness]] *[[Happiness in Judaism]] *[[Self-fulfillment]] *[[Eudaimonia|The good life]] *[[Meaningful life]] *[[Meaning-making]] *[[Logotherapy]] *[[Positive psychology]] *[[World Happiness Report]] *''[[The Happiness Hypothesis]]'' {{div col end}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== {{Sister project links|Happiness}} *Dalai Lama, co-authored with [[Howard C. Cutler]], ''[[The Art of Happiness]]'', 2003. *Jonathan Haidt, ''[[The Happiness Hypothesis: Finding Modern Truth in Ancient Wisdom]]'', 2006. ==External Links== * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p005489g Happiness], BBC Radio 4 discussion with Angie Hobbs, Simon Blackburn and Anthony Grayling (''In Our Time'', Jan. 24, 2002) {{Philosophy topics}} [[Category:Happiness]] [[Category:Belief]] [[Category:Philosophy by topic|Hap]] [[Category:Philosophy of life]]

revision.comment: /* Theoretical background */ falsifiable or falsifiability was already introduced before
revision.text:
"'''Precambrian rabbits'''" or "'''fossil rabbits in the Precambrian'''" are reported to have been among responses given by the biologist [[J.B.S. Haldane]] when asked what [[evidence]] could destroy his confidence in the [[theory of evolution]] and the field of study. The answers became popular [[image]]ry in debates about evolution and the scientific field of [[evolutionary biology]] in the 1990s. Many of Haldane's statements about his scientific research were popularized in his lifetime.
Some accounts use this response to rebut claims that the [[theory]] of evolution is [[Objections to evolution#Evolution is unfalsifiable|not falsifiable]] by any [[empirical evidence]]. This followed an assertion by philosopher, [[Karl Popper]], who had proposed that [[Falsifiability|''falsifiability'']] is an essential feature of a scientific theory. Popper also expressed doubts about the scientific status of evolutionary theory, although he later concluded that the field of study was genuinely scientific.
[[Rabbits]] are [[mammal]]s. From the perspective of the [[philosophy of science]], it is doubtful whether the genuine discovery of mammalian [[fossil]]s in [[Precambrian]] rocks would overthrow the theory of evolution instantly, though if authentic, such a discovery would indicate serious errors in modern understanding about the evolutionary process. Mammals are a class of animals whose emergence in the [[geologic timescale]] is dated to much later than any found in Precambrian strata. Geological records indicate that although the first true mammals appeared in the [[Triassic]] period, modern mammalian orders appeared in the [[Palaeocene]] and [[Eocene]] epochs of the [[Palaeogene]] period. Hundreds of millions of years separate this period from the Precambrian.
==Origin of the phrase==
Several authors have written that J.B.S. Haldane (1892–1964) said that the discovery of a [[fossil]] [[rabbit]] in Precambrian rocks would be enough to destroy his belief in [[evolution]].<ref name="Ridley2004Evolution">{{cite book | title=Evolution | author=[[Mark Ridley (zoologist)|Mark Ridley]] | page=66 | publisher=[[Blackwell Publishing]] | year=2004 | isbn=1-4051-0345-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HCh7n6zuWeUC&pg=PA66&lpg=PA66&dq=precambrian+rabbit | accessdate=2008-10-28 }}</ref><ref name="GodfreySmith2003TheoryAndReality">{{cite book | title=Theory and Reality: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Science | author=[[Peter Godfrey-Smith]] |publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]] | year=2003 | isbn=0-226-30062-5 | pages=72–74 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K3IZqACcSH4C&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73&dq=precambrian+rabbit | accessdate=2008-10-28 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Benton, M.J. | chapter=Testing the Time Axis of Phylogenies | page=222 | title=New Uses for New Phylogenies | editor=Harvey, P.H. |editor2=Brown, A.J.L. |editor3=Smith, J.M. |editor4=Nee, S. | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1996 | isbn =0-19-854984-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YXB6qCkL5U4C&pg=PA222&dq=Maynard+Smith+precambrian+rabbit#PPA222,M1 | accessdate=2008-10-28 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Lane, N. | title=Power, Sex, Suicide: Mitochondria and the Meaning of Life | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | isbn=0-19-280481-2 | page=271 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gMOIt0qNcEMC&pg=PA271&lpg=PA271&dq=haldane+precambrian+rabbit | accessdate=2008-10-28 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Greener, M. | title=Taking on creationism. Which arguments and evidence counter pseudoscience? | journal=EMBO Reports | volume=8 | issue=12 | pages=1107–1109 | year=2007 | doi=10.1038/sj.embor.7401131 | publisher=Nature | pmid=18059309 | pmc=2267227 }}</ref><ref name="Dawkins2005IllusionOfDesign">{{cite journal | author=Dawkins, R. | title=The Illusion of Design | journal=Natural History Magazine | date=November 2005 | url=http://www.naturalhistorymag.com/features/101500/the-illusion-of-design | accessdate=2010-11-15 }}</ref> However these references date from the 1990s or later. In 1996 [[Michael J. Benton]] cited the 1993 edition of [[Mark Ridley (zoologist)|Mark Ridley]]'s book ''Evolution'',<ref name="BentonHitchin1996QualityOfFossilRecord">{{cite journal |author1=Benton, M.J. |author2=Hitchin, R. |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Testing the Quality of the Fossil Record by Groups and by Major Habitats | journal=Historical Biology| year=1996| volume=12 | issue=2 | pages=111–157 | url=http://www.gbhap.com/journals/pdf/ghbi_12_01_03.pdf | accessdate=2008-10-28 | doi=10.1080/08912969609386559 }}</ref> [[Richard Dawkins]] wrote in 2005 that Haldane was responding to a challenge by a "[[Karl Popper|Popperian]] [[zealot]]".<ref name="Dawkins2005IllusionOfDesign" /> In 2004 Richa Arora wrote that the story was told by [[John Maynard Smith]] (1920–2004) in a television programme.<ref>{{cite book | author=Arora, R. | title=Encyclopaedia of Evolutionary Biology | page=18 | publisher=Anmol Publications| year=2004 | isbn=81-261-1500-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a8hOWkH8jOMC&pg=PA18&dq=haldane+precambrian+rabbit+%22maynard+smith%22 | accessdate=2008-10-28 }}</ref> John Maynard Smith attributed the phrase to Haldane in a conversation with [[Paul H. Harvey|Paul Harvey]] in the early 1970s.
==Theoretical background== The philosopher [[Karl Popper]] held that any scientific proposition must be falsifiable, in other words it must at least be possible to [[thought experiment|imagine some reproducible experiment or observation]] whose outcome would disprove the hypothesis.<ref name="Hull1999UseAndAbuseOfPopper" /> Initially he thought that [[Charles Darwin]]'s theory of [[natural selection]] (often summarized as "the survival of the fittest"<ref name=OriginCh4>"This preservation of favourable individual differences and variations, and the destruction of those which are injurious, I have called Natural Selection, or the Survival of the Fittest." — {{Cite book |url=http://www.bartleby.com/br/01101.html |title=The origin of species |author=Charles Robert Darwin. |chapter=IV. Natural Selection; or the Survival of the Fittest |chapter-url=http://www.bartleby.com/11/4001.html |work=The Harvard classics |editor=Charles W. Eliot |publisher=Bartleby.com |year=2001}}</ref>) was untestable in this sense, and therefore "almost [[Tautology (logic)|tautological]]."<ref name="BentonHitchin1996QualityOfFossilRecord" /> Popper later changed his view, concluding that the theory of natural selection is falsifiable and that Darwin's own example of the [[peacock]]'s tail had disproved one extreme variation of it, that ''all'' evolution is driven by natural selection.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Popper, K. | title=Natural Selection and the Emergence of Mind | journal=Dialectica | volume=32 | issue=3–4 | pages=339–355 | year=1978 | doi=10.1111/j.1746-8361.1978.tb01321.x }}</ref> Although in 1978 Popper wrote that his earlier objection had been specifically to the theory of natural selection, in lectures and articles from 1949 to 1974 he had stated that "[[Darwinism]]" or "Darwin's theory of evolution" was a "metaphysical research programme" because it was not falsifiable.<ref>{{cite book | author=Popper, K. | chapter=Darwinism as a Metaphysical Research Programme | pages=302–304 | title=Philosophy of science: Contemporary Readings | editor=Balashov, Y. |editor2=Rosenberg, A. | publisher=Routledge | year=2002 | isbn=0-415-25781-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tAkXVaNq5GAC&pg=PA302&lpg=PA302&dq=natural+selection+is+a+most+successful+metaphysical+research+programme+popper | accessdate=2008-10-28 }}</ref> In fact he continued to express dissatisfaction with contemporary statements of the theory of evolution which focused on [[population genetic]]s, the study of the relative frequencies of [[allele]]s (different forms of the same [[gene]]). Unfortunately some of the adjustments he proposed resembled [[Lamarckianism]] or [[saltation (biology)|saltationism]], evolutionary theories that were and still are considered obsolete, and evolutionary biologists therefore disregarded his criticisms.<ref name="Hull1999UseAndAbuseOfPopper">{{cite journal | author=Hull, D.L. | title=The Use and Abuse of Sir Karl Popper | journal=Biology and Philosophy | volume=14 | issue=4 | date=October 1999 | doi=10.1023/A:1006554919188 | pages=481 }}</ref> In 1981 Popper complained that he had been misinterpreted as saying that "historical sciences" such as [[paleontology]] or the [[evolutionary history of life|history of evolution of life on Earth]] were not genuine sciences, when in fact he believed they could make falsifiable predictions.<ref name="Hull1999UseAndAbuseOfPopper" /><ref>{{cite journal | author=Popper, K.R. | year=1981| title=Evolution| journal=New Scientist | volume=87 | page=611 }}</ref>
Further confusion arose in 1980–1981, when there was a long debate in the pages of ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' about the scientific status of the theory of evolution.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Editorial |title= How true is the theory of evolution? |url= |journal= Nature |volume= 290|issue= 5802 | pages= 75–76 |year= 1981 |pmid=7207599|doi= 10.1038/290075a0|bibcode= 1981Natur.290...75.}}</ref><ref name=johnson>{{cite book| author= Johnson PE|title= Darwin on Trial|year= 2010 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YtrGVVwk5HsC&dq |page= 238 | publisher= InterVarsity Press |isbn= 9780830838318 }}</ref> Specifically, the argument was on the factors influencing and nature of the [[unit of selection]] in the genome, with one side positing natural selection,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Orgel LE, Crick FH |title= Selfish DNA: the ultimate parasite |url= |journal= Nature |volume= 284|issue= 5757 | pages=604–607 |year=1980 |pmid=7366731 |doi= 10.1038/284604a0|bibcode=1980Natur.284..604O}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author= Cavalier-Smith T |title= How selfish is DNA? |url= |journal= Nature |volume= 285|issue= 5767 | pages=617–618 |year=1980 |pmid= 7393317 |doi= 10.1038/285617a0|bibcode= 1980Natur.285..617C}}</ref> and the other, [[Neutral mutation theory|neutral mutation]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dover G, Doolittle WF |title= Modes of genome evolution |url= |journal= Nature |volume=288|issue= 5792 | pages= 646–647 |year=1980 |pmid= 6256636|doi= 10.1038/288646a0|bibcode=1980Natur.288..646D}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Li WH, Gojobori T, Nei M |title= Pseudogenes as a paradigm of neutral evolution |url= |journal= Nature |volume=292|issue= 5820 | pages= 237–239 |year=1981 |pmid= 7254315|doi= 10.1038/292237a0|bibcode=1981Natur.292..237L}}</ref> Neither of the parties seriously doubted that the theory was both scientific and, according to current scientific knowledge, true. Some participants objected to statements that appeared to present the theory of evolution as an absolute dogma, however, rather than as a hypothesis that so far has performed very well, and both sides quoted Popper in support of their positions. Evolution critics such as [[Phillip E. Johnson]] took this as an opportunity to declare that the theory of evolution was unscientific.<ref name="Hull1999UseAndAbuseOfPopper" /><ref name=johnson/>
==Would anachronistic fossils disprove evolution?== Evolutionary biologist [[Richard Dawkins]] said that the discovery of [[fossil mammal]]<nowiki/>s in Precambrian rocks would "completely blow evolution out of the water."<ref>{{Cite news | title=The Evolution Wars | author=Wallis, C. | newspaper=Time | date= August 7, 2005 | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1090909-6,00.html | accessdate=2008-10-29 }}</ref> Philosopher [[Peter Godfrey-Smith]] doubted that a single set of [[anachronistic]] fossils, however, even rabbits in the Precambrian, would disprove the theory of evolution outright. The first question raised by the assertion of such a discovery would be whether the alleged "Precambrian rabbits" really were fossilized rabbits. Alternative interpretations might include incorrect identification of the "fossils", incorrect dating of the rocks, and a [[hoax]] such as the [[Piltdown Man]] was shown to be. Even if the "Precambrian rabbits" turned out to be genuine, they would not instantly refute the theory of evolution, because that theory is a large package of ideas, including: that life on Earth has evolved over billions of years; that this evolution is driven by certain mechanisms; and that these mechanisms have produced a specific "family tree" that defines the relationships among species and the order in which they appeared. Hence, "Precambrian rabbits" would prove that there were one or more serious errors somewhere in this package, and the next task would be to identify those errors.<ref name="GodfreySmith2003TheoryAndReality" />
Benton pointed out that, in the short term, scientists often have to accept the existence of competing hypotheses, each of which explains large parts—but not all—of the observed relevant data.<ref name="BentonHitchin1996QualityOfFossilRecord" />
==Oldest rabbit==
Genuine fossils of earliest rabbits are from the [[Eocene]] [[epoch (geology)|Epoch]], about 56 to 33.9 million years ago. Members of the [[genus]] ''[[Gomphos]]'' are established to be the [[phylogenetic]] root of [[lagomorph]] rabbits and hares.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Asher RJ, Meng J, Wible JR, McKenna MC, Rougier GW, Dashzeveg D, Novacek MJ |url= |title=Stem Lagomorpha and the antiquity of ''Glires'' | journal=Science |volume= 307|issue=5712 |pages= 1091–1094| year= 2005|pmid=15718468 |doi=10.1126/science.1107808|bibcode=2005Sci...307.1091A}}</ref> To date, the oldest ''Gomphos'' is ''G. elkema'' discovered in 2008 from [[Gujarat]], [[India]]. The fossil is dated to 53 million years old.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Rose KD, DeLeon VB, Missiaen P, Rana RS, Sahni A, Singh L, Smith T |url= |title=Early Eocene lagomorph (Mammalia) from Western India and the early diversification of Lagomorpha | journal=Proc Biol Sci |volume=275 |issue= 1639|pages= 1203–1208| year=2008 |pmid= 18285282|pmc=2602686 |doi=10.1098/rspb.2007.1661}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author =National Geographic News |url= http://news.nationalgeographic.co.in/news/2008/03/080321-rabbit-bones_2.html|title= Easter Surprise: World's Oldest Rabbit Bones Found| work= |date=21 March 2008|publisher=National Geographic Society | accessdate=2 August 2013}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Out-of-place artifact]] * [[Paluxy River]] - became famous in 1930s when locals found dinosaur and supposed human footprints in the same rock layer.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Fictional hares and rabbits]] [[Category:Evolutionary biology]] [[Category:History of evolutionary biology]] [[Category:Philosophy of biology]] [[Category:Hypothetical life forms]]

{{Infobox journal | title = Rejuvenation Research | cover = Rejuvenation Research.jpg | image_size = 200px | editor = [[Aubrey de Grey]] | discipline = [[Rejuvenation (aging)|Rejuvenation]] | formernames = Journal of Anti-Aging Medicine | abbreviation = | publisher = [[Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.|Mary Ann Liebert]] | country = | frequency = Bimonthly | history = 1998–present | openaccess = | license = | impact = 3.220 | impact-year = 2017 | website = http://www.liebertpub.com/overview/rejuvenation-research/127/ | link1 = http://www.liebertonline.com/rej | link1-name = Online archives | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = 54674277 | LCCN = 2004214717 | CODEN = | ISSN = 1549-1684 | eISSN = 1557-8577 }} '''''Rejuvenation Research''''' is a bimonthly [[peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] published by [[Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.|Mary Ann Liebert]] that covers research on [[Rejuvenation (aging)|rejuvenation]] and [[biogerontology]]. The journal was established in 1998 and the [[editor-in-chief]] is [[Aubrey de Grey]]. It is the official journal of the European Society of Preventive, Regenerative and Anti-Aging Medicine as well as PYRAMED: World Federation and World Institute of Preventive & Regenerative Medicine.
== History == The journal was established in 1998 as the ''Journal of Anti-Aging Medicine'' with [[Michael Fossel]] ([[Michigan State University]]) as editor-in-chief. It obtained its current title in 2004, when Aubrey de Grey took over as editor-in-chief.
=== SENS conferences === The journal publishes the abstracts of the [[wikt:biennial|biennial]] conferences of the [[SENS Research Foundation]].
== Abstracting and indexing == ''Rejuvenation Research'' is abstracted and indexed in: *[[MEDLINE]] *[[Current Contents]]/Clinical Medicine *[[Science Citation Index Expanded]] *[[EMBASE|EMBASE/Excerpta Medica]] *[[Scopus]] *[[CAB Direct (database)|CAB Abstracts]] According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2017 [[impact factor]] of 3.220.<ref name=WoS>{{cite book |year=2018 |chapter=Rejuvenation Research |title=2017 [[Journal Citation Reports]] |publisher=[[Clarivate Analytics]] |edition=Science |series=[[Web of Science]]}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Strategies for Engineered Negligible Senescence]] * [[Timeline of senescence research]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.liebertpub.com/overview/rejuvenation-research/127/}}

[[File:Chinese_double_happiness_and_longevity_symbol.svg|thumb|The character for double happiness and longevity (''shòu'' 寿)]] [[File:Shou carpet.JPG|thumb|The character for longevity (''shòu'' 寿), that here we can see in one of the traditional highly stylized forms) decorates the four corners of this modern Chinese carpet]] [[File:Shou Yunnan rooftiles.JPG|thumb|Ceramic roof tiles in Yunnan]] [[File:Shou+redbats.JPG|thumb|Flying red bats surround four ''shòu'' characters]] [[File:Shou+peach cup.jpg|thumb|A peach and the character ''shòu'' both representing longevity]] '''''Shòu''''' ({{zh|s=寿|t=壽|p={{audio|Zh-shòu.ogg|shòu|help=no}}}}) is the Chinese word/character for "longevity".
== Use == Three of the most important goals in life in Chinese traditional thought are the propitious blessings of happiness (''fú'' 福), professional success or prosperity (''lù'' 禄), and longevity (''shòu'' 寿). These are visually represented by the three "star gods" of the same names ([[Fu Lu Shou|''Fú, Lù, Shòu'']]), commonly depicted as three male figurines<ref>{{cite book |last=Duda |first=Margaret |title=Traditional Chinese Toggles |publisher=EDM |year=2011 |page=59}}</ref> (each wearing a distinctive garment and holding an object that enables them to be differentiated), or the Chinese ideographs/characters themselves, or various homophones or objects with relevant attributes. ''Shòu'' is instantly recognizable. "He holds in his hand a large peach, and attached to his long staff are a gourd and a scroll. The stag and the bat both indicate ''fu'' happiness. The peach, gourd, and scroll are symbols of longevity."<ref name=werner431>{{cite book |last=Werner |first=E. T. C. |title=A Dictionary of Chinese Mythology |publisher=Kelly and Walsh |year=1932 |page=431}}</ref> His most striking characteristic is, however, his large and high forehead, which earned him the title "Longevity Star Old-pate".<ref name=werner431 />
The Chinese character ''shòu'' (寿) is usually found on textiles, furniture, ceramics and jewelry, generally in its more complex ideograph (壽), but also in its simplified (post-1950) form (寿). The ideograph may appear alone or be surrounded by flowers, bats, or other good luck symbols, but will always hold a central position.
Longevity is commonly recognized as one of the Five Blessings (''wǔfú'' 五福 - longevity, wealth, health, love of virtue, a peaceful death) of Chinese belief<ref>{{cite book |last=Bartholomew |first=Terese Tse |title=Hidden Meanings in Chinese Art |publisher=Asian Art Museum of San Francisco |page=164}}</ref> that are often depicted in the [[homophone|homophonous]] rendition of five flying [[bat]]s because the word for "[[bat]]" in Chinese (''fú'' 蝠) sounds like the word for [[Fu character|"good fortune" or "happiness"]] or in this case, "blessings".<ref>Bartholomew, p. 24</ref> In this arrangement, the ''shòu'' ideograph sometimes takes the dominant central position, replacing the fifth bat.
Other symbols in Chinese iconography that represent longevity include [[Pine|pine trees]], [[Crane (bird)|cranes]], spotted deer, special collectors' stones (''shòushí'' 寿石), [[peach]]es, and [[tortoise]]s.<ref>Duda, pp. 204-6</ref> These are often depicted in small groupings to emphasize the central, symbolic meaning of the picture (for example, cranes standing amongst pine trees).
Perhaps the most common Chinese auspicious saying concerning longevity is that found on scrolls in nearly every Chinese calligraphy shop in the world: ''shòu shān fú hǎi'' (寿山福海), which can be translated as "May your life be as steadfast as the mountains and your good fortune as limitless as the seas".
Since 2017, the version 10 of the [[Unicode]] Standard features a rounded version of the symbol in the "Enclosed Ideographic Supplement" block, at code point U+1F262 (ROUNDED SYMBOL FOR SHOU).<ref name="unicode">{{cite web|title=The Unicode Standard, Version 10.0, Enclosed Ideographic Supplement|url=https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/Unicode-10.0/U100-1F200.pdf|website=unicode.org|publisher=The Unicode Consortium|accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref>
===In names=== As a sign for a resonant cultural concept, the character became a part of many Chinese names (e.g. [[Palace of Tranquil Longevity]] in Beijing). The Japanese equivalent is '''Kotobuki''' 寿 (see [[Nakajima Kotobuki]], [[Tsukasa Kotobuki]]). See also [[Jurōjin]] (Shou Laoren) and [[Fukurokuju]]. {{clear}}
==Gallery== <gallery mode=packed heights=200px> File:Chinese - Pilgrim Bottle with the Character "Shou" (Long Life) - Walters 491685 - Profile.jpg|Chinese pilgrim bottle of "famille rose" porcelain with the character Shou File:Lackkunst Überseemuseum Bremen 2009 PD 20091128 0010.JPG|Song Dynasty lacquer art ''[[Calabash|hulu]]'' with Shou and a bat on it File:Owen Jones - Examples of Chinese Ornament - 1867 - plate 035.png|Plate 35 from the book ''Examples of Chinese Ornament'' by [[Owen Jones (architect)|Owen Jones]] in 1867. The Shou pattern can be seen. File:Owen Jones - Examples of Chinese Ornament - 1867 - plate 039.png|Plate 39 from the same book. The Shou pattern can be seen. File:Owen Jones - Examples of Chinese Ornament - 1867 - plate 052.png|Plate 52 from the same book. The Shou pattern can be seen. File:Owen Jones - Examples of Chinese Ornament - 1867 - plate 058.png|Plate 58 from the same book. The Shou pattern can be seen. File:Owen Jones - Examples of Chinese Ornament - 1867 - plate 073.png|Plate 73 from the same book. The Shou pattern can be seen. File:Owen Jones - Examples of Chinese Ornament - 1867 - plate 086.png|Plate 86 from the same book. The Shou pattern can be seen. File:Plat au caractère Shou Musée Guimet 2418.jpg|Porcelain dish with a peach tree in the form of Shou, from the [[Kangxi Emperor|Kangxi period]] in the [[Qing dynasty]] File:Shou by Hai Rui.jpg|Shou character written by [[Hai Rui]] at [[Qiandao Lake]]. The character can be viewed either right-side up or upside down to read "Shou". </gallery>
==See also== * [[Fu character]] (福) * [[Double Happiness (calligraphy)]] (囍), a common calligraphic good-luck design

Elaine Spaulding Atwood |title=The Five Happinesses: Symbolism in Chinese Popular Art |location=New York |publisher=Weatherhill |year=1973}} *{{cite book |editor=Li Zuding |title=Chinese Traditional Auspicious Patterns |publisher=Shanghai Popular Science Press |year=1989}} *{{cite book |last=Ridley |first=Michael |title=Style, Motif and Design in Chinese Art |location=Dorset |publisher=Blandford Press |year=1977}} *{{cite book |last=Welch |first=Patricia Bjaaland |title=Chinese Art: A Guide to Motifs and Visual Imagery |publisher=Tuttle Publishing |year=2008}}

'''Sky burial''' may refer to:
;Funerary practices * [[Sky burial]] ({{bo|t=བྱ་གཏོར་|w=bya gtor}}, <small>lit.</small> "bird-scattered") a Tibetan open-air excarnation funerary practice * [[Dakhma]] (Persian: دخمه ; Avestan: <small>lit.</small>  “tower of silence”) a Zoroastrian open-air excarnation funerary practice * [[Space burial]], a space-age funerary practice involving launching cremated remains into space
;Other uses * [[Sky Burial]] (2004 novel) by Xue Xinran
==See also== * [[Burial (disambiguation)]]
